It did however, contribute to that over-saturation of zombies in the horror genre, which I absolutely hate. They‚Äôre far too overdone, but the story did take them on in a newer and more interesting light.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
I do not think highly of this game when it 1st came out for the PS3, but man did I not think for 1 second it was going to suck this hard. Nonsensical storyline, very easy to die in (I died in the prologue for christ's sake), too easy to get lost in (and not in a good way) and these are the complaints I have off the top of my head. The worst part about this is that I was dying on the easiest difficulty setting (believe it or don't; not caring). The game did arrive in really good shape, which is the only thing that redeems the game for me. That redeeming quality is within Amazon and not the game itself, so that point's rendered moot. The only reason this game gets 1 star is because it's the lowest one could give piece of garage products like this game. I'd personally and gladly give it 0 stars if I could (or even negative stars because I dislike the game that much).

1st time reviewing products on Amazon and on mobile, so I'm sorry for any and all spelling, pronunciation and/or format errors.
titles: How is this game considered to be a masterpiece?

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents: This game feels like being inside the world of The Walking Dead. Gameplay is challenging enough but slow at times. The zombies/monsters are pretty cool. Some are hard to figure out how to destroy (but that's part of the fun). Character acting is not nearly as bad as many games. If you're looking for a storyline-based game that you can play in your leisure time and you like zombies, this is worth a look.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
I love this game. I love the story and I love the mechanics of the actual gameplay.

I was nervous about spending the whole game getting killed, so my first playthrough was on Easy. I have now played it through several times, on every level of difficulty, and I'm still not tired of playing it.

I appreciate that it's a third-person view game, as first-person ones tend to make me nauseous.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents: The game, game play and story live up to the hype. It's a post apocalypse infected (zombies even if they choose a different word) wasteland. You come across some well known cities and towns. The characters and their development are well worth it. I am looking forward to its sequel most definitely.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents: The Last of Us's premise isn't unique. It takes place in a post apocalyptic America overrun with mushroom zombies. The strength of The Last of Us lies within it's well written Characters and game play mechanics. You're constantly looking out for supplies trying to craft items used to outsmart your enemies. While you can fight enemies head on it's best to stick to the shadows and plan out your attacks. I think this is a game that everyone should experience.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
Are most Gamers ignorant and naive ? Are there any intelligent Gamers out there? Do you not realize that most if not all PlayStation 4 games don't let you save the game where you want to,or when you want to... so you can go back and play the section of the game that you like.... whenever you want to ?

If there are any intelligent Gamers out there I hope you realize PlayStation 4 makers obviously got together with gaming programmers and insisted that 'they take away the option of us being able to save games when we want to and as often we want to' so that we can go back and play the game in the section that we love as often as we would like too !

The obvious reason for them taking away our options to save the game when we want to and where we want to is so that we will get bored of the game sooner or later and buy a new game instead of being able to play the sections of the games that we love whenever we want to !

( There would be tons of replay value in any good game if we could save the section that we love and come back and play it as often as we would like to !!!!!! )

The gaming industry has purposely gone out of their way to make sure that we don't have the option to play the game the way that we want to as often as we would like to !!!!

STOP BUYING GAMES THAT DON'T GIVE YOU THE OPTION TO SAVE WHERE YOU WANT !!!!
STOP BUYING GAMES THAT DON'T GIVE YOU THE OPTION TO SAVE AND PLAY ONLY THE SECTIONS OF THE GAMES THAT YOU LIKE/LOVE !!!!
titles: STOP BUYING GAMES THAT DON'T GIVE YOU THE OPTION TO SAVE AND PLAY THE SECTIONS YOU LIKE !!!

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents: This game is phenomenal. Most zombie games involve getting the biggest gun and fire away. That strategy is disasterous in this game. The Last of Us is more about sneaking and conserving ammunition than it is about killing zombies. I highly recommend getting this game, playing at night, and turning the lights off. The story is suspenseful, the game is challenging, and the gameplay is intense.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
Everybody raved about hthis game and since I've really enjoyed the Uncharted series from the same studio, I finally gave in and played it.

It's visually impressive and the voice acting is so good that you start to become attached to the main characters even if the story is a bit clich√©d and generic.

My only real complaint is that it's not true that this is an open-world game and gameplay is pretty meh compared to the visuals and audio. Just generic stealth and generic gunfigths with generic post-apocalyptic bandits and soldiers, and three kinds of "zombies."

The game's saving grace is the story, which starts a bit slow and is reasonably generic for a "zombie apocalypse" yarn, but it really grabs you once it gets going by focusing on the way the relationship between the two main characters, Joel and Ellie, develops thanks to very solid voice acting and great cut-scenes, which immerse you in the game despite the aforementioned weaknesses regarding gameplay.

The version I got also included the DCL "Left Behind," in which you play only as Ellie and is a sort of prequel that in parallel also fills some narrative holes in the original game, which I thought was pretty cool.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
I was always hesitant about playing this game because scary games aren't usually my thing. As I've gotten older though, I've found that giving games a try is better than writing them off because they might be scary. I've never been more happy to have decided to pick this game up.

The story blew me away and left my heart aching. The pure heartwrenching moment of Sarah's death at the beginning and how that changed Joel's character really showed what loss can do to a person. I also really enjoyed how Ellie and Joel's relationship developed throughout the game - how they grew to care and trust one another. And that ending - brilliant. This game makes you second guess how you'd react in the same situation and really think about humanity as a whole.

Am I good a shooter games? Absolutely not, but the story made me keep trying even when I kept dying during a couple of parts in the game.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
Back when i had ps3, for some dumb reason i nevee got my hands on this game, eventho my friends always spoke the best words about it. Finally i get to experience it, ans let me tell ya...its PRETTY MUCH A BOMB EXPERIENCE! In terms of graphics and beautiful crafted environments, to amazing, intriguing and full of emotions story plot!
The battle and action elements of the game are pretty challenging and they demand u to think strategically throughout your enemies.
The story is the strongest point of last of us, as it will literally ‚Äúsuck U in‚Äù and get u really involved in its plot! The environment and graphics are gorgeous as it makes u think, how it would feel to be there!
This game is a MUST have for any gamer hardcore or not. Truly a masterpiece one of its kind!!!
titles: ONE OF THE BEST GAMES EVER MADE! TRULY A GEM!

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents:
This is supposed to be one of the all-time great games and I just don't get it. It's a completely linear storyline - you don't get to make any decisions about anything. It's just standard clear out an area, scavenge for stuff, upgrade your weapons, maybe watch a cut scene, and go to the next area and repeat.

I know the "greatness" is supposed to be the relationship between the characters, but you don't get to actually participate in it. There are no dialog choices or anything. You're just watching a movie. It's no different than hundreds of other games.

product_name: The Last of Us Remastered Hits - PlayStation 4
review_contents: I have been playing games since the early 80s, and I can honestly state that this is the pinnacle of gaming that I have experienced. I was a bit skeptical for about the first hour or two of gameplay, but the more I played, the more the game flowed. There are a variety of strikingly different areas, different characters, and different scenarios to experience. The difficulty level on "easy" is not TOO easy; there are plenty of sections that I had to replay a couple of times, but not so difficult that I wanted to give up. If you enjoy single player adventure games, then this is a no-brainer; highly recommended!
titles: Exceptional single player game (for an old gamer)

review_contents

This is the worst Pokemon game ever. As someone who has played every mainline entry since the original Pokemon Red and Blue, I am particularly disappointed to see the quality of Pokemon games declining for the past few years. First, over 60% of all Pokemon have been cut and do not appear in any playable form in this game. All previous starters except the Charizard line and all previous legendaries, for example, have been removed by Game Freak. I have been training my Blastoise since Pokemon FireRed and transferring him to each new generation. I never thought I would see the day I could not play with Blastoise in a mainline Pokemon game. Game Freak's excuses are also unforgivable. The Pokemon models and animations are the same as those since Pokemon X and Y. The Nintendo 64 game Pokemon Stadium has superior, livelier animations than this Switch game. And they are charging $20 dollars for less Pokemon, costly Internet, and recycled models.

Look, instead, go buy Fire Emblem: Three Houses, Dragon Quest XI or The Witcher 3. These masterpieces offer a superior story, engaging battle mechanics, and modern visuals. It's a shame that Pokemon has fallen. Super Mario Odyssey and Breath of the Wild set the benchmark of what a Nintendo franchise can offer on the Switch. However, Pokemon Sword and Switch have set a new low for the series. To buy this game is to perpetuate low standards in a multimillion franchise and corporate greed from Game Freak's part. Save Pokemon and boycott Sword and Shield!

In short, this game is awful for advanced players, mediocre for casual player and it's desirable that this is nobody's first Pok√©mon game, least they get the wrong impression. It is the worst Pok√©mon main duo ever released and the only positive aspects are derived from the standard Pok√©mon formula. Being understaffed isn't even remotely enough to explain the unacceptable low quality of these games; GameFreak has serious leadership issues.

This trash heap is the result of complacency, and a lack of effort and dedication. If it had been developed with care and the consumer's satisfaction in mind, it would have been a polished title with a lot of content complementing the new features. Sadly, this is not the case.

Bugs, no endgame, half pokedex, mediocre graphics, less features than previous games...should I keep talking? Save your money and don't buy this dumpster fire of a game.
titles: The only reason it gets one star is because I can't give it a 0 star rating

review_contents: Minimal effort from Game Freak. I've waited YEARS for this, and we get a subpar game. Oh well, at least I have Animal Crossing to look forward to. #GameFreakLied

Absolutely sad excuse for a game, this is quite possible the worst game from any top developer in the past decade (not just GameFreak). Nintendo should be ashamed to be associated with this garbage. A very short list of issues:
- Graphics are OBJECTIVELY worse than Let's Go Pikachu and I would argue they're worse than Pokemon USUM. This terrible excuse for graphics is why we lost over half of all Pokemon in the game? What a load of garbage.
- We lost over half of all Pokemon in the game. Not just uncatchable, but they're not even in the game, you can't transfer into the games because they excluded excluded metadata for them and decided to exclude EXISTING Pokemon models from the game, which is what they did for other Pokemon.
- Only 80 new Pokemon overall. They didn't even try.
- Their new Pokemon battle concept is essentially: "Look, the Pokemon is now bigger! See how big it is? Pretty cool, huh?" No creativity, it sounds like a throwaway idea someone said jokingly during a meeting that they took as a serious comment and went with it. It's the stupidest thing I've ever heard of.
- You'd think that Pokemon becoming bigger versions of themselves would mean Pokemon size would be an important thing to scale. Nope. They have Wailord shown as being slightly smaller as the 4'10" trainer (~150 cm). Wailord is supposed to be a 50 ft (~15m) long behemoth. But nope, huge (literally) details are no longer important.
- Finally, the straw that broker the camel's back: the game froze when I was battling in the Ice-gym. I had auto-save on, but also kept manually saving anyway because I couldn't trust anything in the game at that point. When I restarted the game after it froze, the save point there was in Route 6, basically half the game ago.

At that point I juts gave up on the game. I lost half the progress because this terrible-developed game couldn't bother to QA their garbage product. I'm going to try to return the game, but doubt I'll be able to. This left a bad taste in my mouth and I may never buy another Pokemon game again unless management changes and they start making respectable games again.
titles: Worst game by top developer in the past decade - unfinished, buggy, disappointing

review_contents:
The Good:
-Its Pok√©mon...
-Slight Upgrade on graphics (Compared to Lets Go Pikachu).
-First (Next Gen) Pok√©mon to come to the switch.
-At least for me it seemed faster loading for battles..compared to sun/moon
The BAD:
-The story is below average.
-The pacing is slow.(Very Linear).
-The writing is sub par for Pok√©mon games.
The UGLY:
It‚Äôs pretty sad to see my favorite series hit a new low. Am I surprised no, because no matter how anyone feels about the game (liked or disliked), the game still sells the same every generation. So they don‚Äôt really care about feedback. You would think with all the money they‚Äôve made through this franchise, that they‚Äôd atleast try to make it more unique, better, and innovative.

I would only recommend to those who just love Pok√©mon as a series, but if you‚Äôre expecting something new and innovative, this might not be the game you‚Äôre looking for
titles: The Good, The Bad, And the Ugly

review_contents: This game is exactly like the older versions (red, blue, yellow, etc.) but with better graphics/gameplay! I opened it and have not stopped playing since I got it! You level up your Pokemon through BATTLES with wild Pokemon, trainers, or gym leaders. Gotta catch them all!
My children are 4,6,9 the game has problem solving reading and exploring my husband and I are pokemon fans happy to have our children join the fun as well
I am noticing a ton of technical issues reminiscent of the quality of a 3DS port. The game is not worth $60 and I expect to see it cheaper in a matter of months.

Definitely regret buying this game. Got it as a time waster, but the selection of pokemon is poor and small compared to other games. Never been into pokemon, and I think I picked the low point of the series to jump in. The animations for the mons are laughably lazy and consist primarily of static translation or rotation, no moving limbs or anything, though it appears this may get better with more advanced pokemon. Its incredibly disappointing to be able to weaken a pokemon only to find the game has hard locked your ability to capture it behind badges. No nearly impossible rng capture odds, just a flat "nope, get on with the scripted gameplay". The game makes a huge deal out of the "dynamax" gimmick, despite it being nothing more than increasing the size and raw stats of the pokemon. Grinding persists, and I very much doubt game play will increase in depth beyond "make sure you have type advantage and comparable level".
At-least I can make my trainer look cool.
titles: Standard aaa; dusted with glitter and hollow

review_contents:
I hate people who are being toxic to this game. Sure, it cuts down on a bunch of pokemon and is lacking in some ways, but this has actually been one of the more fun pokemon games. I have been around since gen 6, but have played every gen multiple times so believe me when I say that I know that this game is good

Pros:
Character interaction is amazing, and you actually bond with the other characters.

You have 3 rivals: your best friend (not cheesy at all though), some guy who looks down on you (haven't someone like that since gen 2), and a girl with her own cheering squad (ok, I guess).

The combat system is the same, but it feels as though battling is harder (idk how), making it more exciting.

New pokemon look amazing, including some very original pokemon, although there is another new bird, bug, and mammel pokemon like every gen.

This game also happens to be the first one where I can't tell who is the bad guy upon first meeting. I now know who, but it wasn't who I expected it to be.

Cons:
Less Routes, and this game makes it easy to avoid wild pokemon as you can see them, which means there is no surprise to seeing a new pokemon in battle.

Also, animations for certain moves and pokemon are eh.

Neutral:
Cutscenes exist, but no voices, only text

I haven't completed the game yet, but from what I have picked up, it is a great game. It is true that it lacks in some areas, but that is after OVERLOOKING what is good about this game. Tbh, I am just happy that it is an imptovement on top of gen 7.
2 hour intro, No national Dex, sprites are Re-used from 3DS. Empty space and not enough Type Balance in the combat.

This game is awful period. Wide open worlds with nothing to do, the towns have like 4 shops and 3 homes where you can talk to people with one line of dialouge, the new pokemon look really bad, no villains, the story somehow is worse than every other pokemon game and it looks like trash. The only thing I wanna catch is my refund

These games had so much potential: new hardware, a chance to take what worked well from Let's Go, a fan base itching for a new installment to follow up to previous greats like Sun & Moon and X & Y. And yet...it just doesn't turn the enginer over. There are so many great ideas in this game, but so much left unpolished and an overall feeling of being rushed. As a diehard player from the very original GB games with Red and Blue, this is difficult to write. I want to like it, I really really do. But it's just not there :/

Poor decisions by Gamefreak put the nails in the coffin for the declining essence of being a Pok√©mon trainer. Be prepared to find an abundance of every resource possible, making the game a breeze, disconnected with your effort and inflated. The graphics and animations are barren for a 30 fps game. Many features are removed in the place of nonsense. The map is tiny. The story is shallow and disrupted frequently by friendly "rivals". For villain hideouts, we get elevator music and cheering.

Save yourself time and money and go play literally any other switch game.

The game looks beautiful. There are many things that I strongly dislike about it. The camera angle gets annoying at times because it will go from being able to look around anyway you want to strictly a side view only.

During battles there are these random pan outs that last maybe a few milliseconds which becomes an eye sore when playing for awhile; completely useless. There are times where it feels less like a "map" and more of a horizontal tower with few levels to climb "up" to advance.

There is a long stretch until you reach your first gym, and then very short stretches in between gyms. I've had some 1v1 trainer battles that sweep me, but gym battles that I sweep with just a single pokemon.

This game feels very rushed and I am not thrilled with it. I came from playing leaf green, to this. I find myself going back to leaf green rather pokemon sword.

Dynamaxing pokemon is very corny. Doesnt even feel original anymore.
titles: It's an okay game, but I'm probably going back to the originals.

review_contents:
I would like to announce that I am one of the individuals that had a console brick because of this game. Be very aware of this issue and play this game at your own risk.

THIS GAME AT RELEASE BRICKS SWITCH HARDWARE
BUYER BEWARE!!!

Thoughts on the game itself:
The game looks like something that should have been on the Wii. Animations are bare bones, environments are empty and the pop-in/lag are everywhere. The Wild Areas have some serious optimization issues and can be extremely jittery at times. Honestly, this game should have been in development another year or two to optimize gameplay and bugs but TPCI is to blame for this series becoming a yearly release cash grab.

The only real fun my son and I had were exploring the wild area and battling high level raid bosses. But this gets a bit old since you kind of get railroaded through the main game with overleveling being an issue after the second gym.

Gym mechanics have been changed for the best but it's a real shame that there is zero replay in this game other than trying to complete your dex and raid battling.

Random trades are back and it's a nightmare. I spent probably most of release night trying to get a decent trade but instead were rewarded with 7-8 or Digletts renamed with a capital N. Seriously, this community is cancerous.

Pros:
-New features and streamlining of old ones to create a decent switch Pokemon title.
-Pro-Controller support (END THE WAGGLE GIMICKS, thanks for giving us a friggin CHOICE)
-Good character customization

Cons:
-Switch finally bricked today 11/16 due to the poor optimization of this game.
-Looks like a Wii era game and isn't worth $60
-No national dex, Pokemon Home is another scam to waste your time and money holding on to Pokemon that can't be transferred to future titles
-Its the same old tired formula with less features than previous titles, less Pokemon and railroaded main story
titles: Looks and feels like a decade too late

review_contents: The game has a lot of sub par graphics. It has loading issues, pop in issues, and a lot of stuttering and stopping. Design wise, the new pokemon are not good, they are very phoned in and very unintersting, and simply feel like they were rushed in doing them. The whole game feels extremely rushed. There is about 40 minutes of post game, there is an incredibly simply battle tower and thats it. The online modes suffer a lot from not having any meaniful or fun modes. The main story is incredibly easy, like no need to think easy mode, and only takes 8 hours. The main story is underwhelming and border line just bad. Plz Plz do not buy this game. Its not worth it.
titles: The game has a lot of Technical issues and a lot of design problems

review_contents:
üí° If you're playing this between 11/15/2019 to 01/15/2020, you can get a Mystery Gift Meowth that can turn gigantic. Use the "Get via Internet" option.

üí° You get a fishing rod before you even leave your hometown, so make sure to fish around Route 2. There's a spot near the Professor's house that's perfect for chaining Magikarp early on.

üí° Buy pokeballs in multiples of 10 each time so you can get a bonus Premier Ball for every set of 10.

üí° Talk to the Ball Guy. He might or might not be creepy, ymmv, but he'll give you free pokeballs.

üí° Mystery Gift codes for special pokeballs. Choose the "Get with Code/Password" option. (Redeemable only until January 15, 2020):
K0UN1NMASC0T (Fast Ball, Level Ball, Moon Ball)
1YAHAYA (Beast Ball, Heavy Ball, Lure Ball)
0KUGAFUKA1B0RU (Dream Ball, Friend Ball, Love Ball)

üí° Mystery Gift code for 20BP, available until January 30, 2020: G1GANTAMAX

üí° If you see a sparkle on the ground/rocks/surroundings, pick it up, it's a free item.

üí° Get a Gigantamax Eevee and Gigantamax Pikachu from the children in the Wild Area Station. All you need is a savefile from Let's Go Eevee and Let's Go Pikachu. Borrow a friend/family member's cartridge to create a save file, you don't have to finish the game, you just need the data.

üí° Items in the Wild Area respawn after a day. Try to visit every day so you can collect all the mushrooms and things that you could sell to make bank. Sidenote: A Breeder loiters in different spots in the Wild Area where you can challenge her a few times a day; her team consists of all the starters.

üí° Defeat and/or catch all the pokemon that emit a super saiyan-like aura to get Watts. You can spend your Watts to buy specialty balls, one-use TRs, or other items from different sellers all over the Wild Area. If a fisherman offers you a mystery item they've caught on their line, buy it. It's more likely to be a pearl/big pearl/pearl string that you can sell to the shops for a lot of cash.

üí° Visit the Battle Cafes every day to battle the Cafe Master. In addition to prize money, he'll give you a sweet to give to Milcery so that it can evolve into Alcremie. Give Milcery the sweet, then continuously rotate the left control stick until your character is spinning in a pirouette. After the spin, your character will do Leon's Charizard Pose and Milcery will evolve. (There are 63 forms and 7 shiny variations, and they all depend on how you spun to do the victory pose - clockwise or counter-clockwise, the time of day, and the number of spins.)

üí° Galarian Linoone will evolve into Obstagoon when you level it up at night from level 35 and up.

üí° How to evolve Galarian Yamask to Runerigus? Yamask has to have at least 49HP damage from one battle and not faint from it, then you have to go under the bridge on the Dusty Bowl. I gave my low level Yamask a Focus Band, made sure it was in front, took a hit that it only survived due to the Focus Band, switched it out for a stronger pokemon, defeated opponent pokemon, then traveled to the Dusty Bowl bridge. You'll know the second you've found the right place because Yamask instantly evolves.

üí° Fight as many Max Raid battles as you could. You don't have to invite people, the game will generate random NPCs for you, and the rewards are very generous.

üí° Eevee can be found on Route 4, among the wheat grass. They're rarer than Pikachus, so you might have to go to Turffield and back a few times; go heal your team in the Pokemon Center or something, and then go back to where the Eevee cosplayers are. They spawn visibly, but blend in really well with the wheat, so keep a keen eye out.

Once your bike can ride on water, there's also an Eeveelution that respawns every day on Lake of Outrage.

üí° Ditto can be found on the Lake of Outrage in the Wild Area, near Hammerlocke. It's only accessible after you've upgraded your bike to be able to ride on water. They spawn visibly and also in random encounters.

üí° Visit Lake of Outrage every day for evolution stones.

üí° Don't worry about the 'limited' amount of Boxes. The game adds more as you fill the Boxes up.

üí° The more times you shake Berry Trees, the bigger the chance of a pokemon falling on you. You then have to battle/run away from it, and you will end up with only one or no berries. (I usually stop at 2 shakes.)

üí° Eggs will inherit their parent's pokeball, with the exception of the Master Ball and Cherish Balls. These two pokeballs are not inheritable.

Ditto + Male pokemon = male pokemon's pokeball.
Male + Female of the same species = 50-50 chances of inheriting either one.
Female pokemon + Ditto/other compatible male pokemon = Female pokemon's pokeball.

üí° Try to get the Shiny Charm to increase odds of encountering shinies. How? Collect all the pokemon. All 400 of them.

üí° Combine Shiny Charm with Masuda Method in breeding to further increase possibilities of shinies. Masuda Method is using pokemon from 2 different languages. (Example: Japanese Ditto + English Ponyta.)

üí° Visit Leon's room in your hometown after you become Champion, he left you a gift Charmander.

‚úîÔ∏è Only need to catch 400 pokemon to get the Shiny Charm.

‚úîÔ∏è No need for a Moss Rock or Ice Rock anymore. To evolve Eevee into a Leafeon, use a Leaf Stone. To evolve it into a Glaceon, use an Ice Stone.

‚úîÔ∏è No need for a special magnetic field anymore either. To evolve Charjabug into a Vikavolt, use a Thunder Stone.

‚úîÔ∏è There's a mini quest to catch Zacian/Zamazenta after you become the Champion. It's not as big a quest as becoming the League Champion, but it's still fun.

‚úîÔ∏è Very easy to grind. Exp Share is activated right at the beginning of the journey, so the team levels up together fast.

‚úîÔ∏è Wild Area is like if the Safari Zone, Join Avenue, Festival Plaza, Entralink, and Friend Safari had a baby, but much MUCH better. It's great for grinding and earning cash. Items sold to shops respawn every day and there are several other ways to obtain them, like the fishermen who sell you pearls for Watts or the roaming Breeder. If you're connected Online, passing trainers appear all throughout. If you talk to them they'll give you free stuff.

‚úîÔ∏è Specialty pokeballs are easily accessible very early on in the game.

‚úîÔ∏è No need for HM slaves.

‚úîÔ∏è 2 Day Cares. One is on Route 5, the other on Bridge Field of the Wild Area.

‚úîÔ∏è Leaving pokemon in the Day Cares cost a flat fee of 500credits each. Slight con is that they don't level up the pokemon anymore, but it's easy to grind in the game and it's worth it not to pay astronomical amounts every time you leave a super low level pokemon, spend a lot of time breeding shinies out of it, and then having to pay A LOT to take it out.

‚úîÔ∏è Pokemon Camp, Pokemon Amie's replacement. You can play with all 6 of your pokemon instead of only one, and you can cook for them using berries and other ingredients. They gain Exp as well as Friendship Points. You can visit other people's Camps and change the looks of your tent.

‚úîÔ∏è Galarian Forms. Corsola, Darumaka, Farfetch'd, Meowth, Mr. Mime, Ponyta, Stunfisk, Weezing, Yamask, and Zigzagoon. Galarian Evolutions of Cursola, Obstagoon,Mr. Rime, Perrserker, Renerigus, and Sirfetch'd.

‚úîÔ∏è New kind of shiny. The sparkles are squares instead of stars.

‚úîÔ∏è Surprise Trade is the new and improved Wonder Trade. It's faster, and can be done in the background once you've initialized the first few steps.

‚ùå Surprise Trades need internet connection and you'll only be able to trade online if you have a Nintendo Switch Online Membership, unlike in previous generations where you only needed wifi.

‚ùå ymmv, but the shiny effect is kind of unsatisfying this gen? Before, it was as satisfying as the sound effects of unsheathing a sword and then clashing metal. Now it's so... subtle. It's so subtle, I almost missed out on my first shiny encounter this gen. If I hadn't looked down and noticed it was an odd color, I would've totally skipped out on it.

‚ùå No Pokemon Amie, it's been replaced by Pokemon Camp.

‚ùå No National Pokedex.

‚ùå No new Eeveelution. This would've been a perfect time to do a steel type eevee, to go with the sword/shield theme.

‚ùå No Pokemon Bank. (As of yet.) Reports say there's gonna be a Pokemon Home on 2020.

‚ùå Can't transfer pokemon from Let's Go games.

‚ùå No GTS. If you only have one game/console and want a version exclusive, you need to use the Y-Comm to throw that request into the ether and hope someone replies to it.

‚ùå Some really useful TMs are now TRs. Technical Records are the new Technical Machines and they're one-use only. Really useful moves like Flamethrower, Ice Beam, Aura Sphere, Thunderbolt, Surf, Shadow Ball, Psychic just to name a few. They're only attainable as Max Raid battle rewards or purchased by Watts.
titles: don't forget your Gigantamax Meowth! (Eevee & Ditto locations)

review_contents: Where to begin, for one though the story and gameplay seem like your standard pokemon game at first this deviates wildly when you realize you can no longer catch high level pokemon if you don't possess enough badges. Secondly the wild area and dynamax raids seem fine until you reach the postgame where they become an absolute nightmare due to artificial difficulty and god awful Npc designs. This is seen most clearly in Npc's that use a magikarp or other first line pokemon to fight what is more or less this game's closest thing to legendaries, the gigantamax pokemon which you have extremely limited lives to fight but are nigh unobtainable in an actual online cooperative raid due to extremely lowered catch rates, forcing players to solo with said Npc's. Which brings me to the point of the online play, whenever I'm not being randomly dropped from trades or battles, which no longer have friend to friend matchmaking but instead use a 4 digit code system to 'connect' players who know eachother, I'm lamenting the lack of the Global Trade System which Gamefreak pioneered on the DS. The main story is a complete cakewalk with minimal dialog and actual depth compared to previous entries and there is a major game breaking glitch in the post game where not using the only master ball in the game on the version exclusive legendary(yes it is only caught in post game) can result in your game crashing repeatedly. Now onto the latest gimmick of dynamaxing and gigantamaxing, dynamax would be nice if you could use it anywhere but sadly it can only be used in 3 select instances: gym battles, raids and story battles. As for gigantamax it is bad enough that the pokemon capable of doing so have a dismal spawn rate, but their inability to pass on the trait that allows them to gigantamax and the significantly lowered catch rates compared to every other pokemon in the game makes them hardly worth obtaining. As far as the positives for the game go it does meet the definition of a pokemon game and I don't discourage others from playing it, however read the above grievances should any of those gameplay aspects weigh in on your decision to purchase.

1) This is what happen if a company realize that they can do anything and people keep buying their products. Pokemon Sword and Shield are the worst mainline Pokemon game to date. Gamfreaks cuts more than 50% of Pokemon, removing moves, mega evolutions, and endgame contents without adding any improvement they promised. Most of the Pokemon model is proven identical to 3ds pokemon model which means they lied, because in the interview they said the reason they can't bring all the Pokemon is because they had to make all the models from scratch which is proven is not the case

2)I really wish the games were good. I don't leave this review out of spite, but because I love the series. For the positives, I like some of the new designs. On top of that, most Pokemon get additional moves, giving them more variety in combat. Besides that, it's a Pokemon game with serious added flaws. Though it was a trend set in earlier games, the new games are more linear and less secret filled than ever. Dungeons are more akin to hallways instead labyrinths with branching paths and abundant secrets. There are very few routes in the game, and the ones that exist are mostly short and lack complexity. The wild area feels half baked and unfinished. After the short main campaign, all that's left for you is a short side story and a Battle Tower. Besides that, you're entirely reliant on playing online for content.

As a gimmick, Dynamax against other players is frustrating and poorly balanced. One wrong move and you're down two or even three mons. This is especially devastating in 3v3 matches, it feels even more poorly balanced than the previous battle gimmicks, Mega Evolution and Z-moves.

It's painful to see the series hit this low. I wanted this to be good, but wading through the major flaws to get to the small nuggets of good simply isn't worth it. The games aren't irredeemable, but it's really hard to recommend it when it drops the ball so hard
titles: Not worth the 60 dollar price tag. Easy game with a short story.

review_contents:
Wow, where to even begin.

I begin my Pok√©mon journey on Pok√©mon blue edition back on the OG game boy. Ever since then I fell in love with Pok√©mon and played all the games up until the 3DS games due to college and such. This is the first Pok√©mon game that I have played since coming back into it and let me just tell you I‚Äôve never been so disappointed so much in a Nintendo game in my life before.

First off, the XP share makes the game way way too easy. It used to be a hassle to try to level up a Magikarp But now it is so easy to get a Gyarados it‚Äôs kinda dumb easy. Back in my day in order to Catch up One pocket monster to get to the level of the rest of Your Pok√©mon you would have to put it on your hot bar first to where it comes out and then hurry up and switch it to one of your other stronger Pok√©mon because back then any Pok√©mon who is in the battle would share XP. But now every single Pok√©mon in your party gets XP.

The rendering distance is awful. You can see the artwork in the background and everything just fine but you can‚Äôt see NPCs and Pok√©mon until your 10 feet away. I know that the switch isn‚Äôt exactly a powerhouse when it comes to hardware but I know that it‚Äôs better than that.

I read somewhere online that game freak cut a bunch of Pok√©mon so you can perfect it‚Äôs animations but honestly with the exception of a few special animations they all look kind of generic. Again with the previous point I know that the switches hardware isn‚Äôt exactly the best but I know it‚Äôs better than this.

Overall the game is just plain to easy. The campaign is too short. The story is predictable and the new Pokemon is just ‚Äòeh.‚Äô This game made me realize that my golden days of video games has long past me and new editions of my favorite game series back in the day are only to get the younger generation to enjoy it. I can‚Äôt say I blame them, but dang it it makes me sad
titles: I wanted to like this game so bad...

review_contents: This game rides off the success of Pokemon Lets Go, and offers nothing new of value worth the money. New pokemon are far and few between, with many designs being lackluster and unsatisfying to play. Very disappointed I purchased this.
All You Do is Check your Email after a Few Minutes & There's an Email with your Code. Hop on the Eshop on your Switch, Enter the Code & Download!

The game can be fun, however the quality of the game is lacking, to say the least. The graphics are horrendous. When you have games on the Switch like Breath of the Wild, there is absolutely NO reason why you should have a game that looks like this. There is next to no detail in the game. Honestly, the graphics quality reminds me of games I played on N64, and that was 20 years ago. If you don't really care and just want a fun Pokemon game, then have at it. Just know that they also cut a HUGE number of pokemon from the game, and after seeing the final product, there doesn't appear to be a reason why.

IMHO this game is nowhere near worth the $60 price tag. If you can score the game for $20-30 max I would say go for it, but until you can find it for that price I would not buy this game.

There are plenty of great games that are aimed at kids. There are plenty of great Pokemon games. This is not one of them. Bad optimization. Bad pop in. Bad options. Nintendo should just hand the reigns over to another developer since GameFreak seems to be so terribly lazy. Don't buy this game for full price, it's not worth it. I hate to sound like everyone else, but this really should have been the Breath of the Wild of the Pokemon series. If it was made by a competent developer of course.

EDIT: Upon further review, I was wrong. After 200 hours of play, I can safely say this is a good game. With the addition of an expanded Pokedex and Pokemon Home, there's plenty of content in the game right now. Revising to 3 stars. I still wish the base game/story were longer, more detailed.

I've played every game since the original Red/Blue. This one is a disappointment. It could have been so much more. It feels rushed. It feels like a Sun/Moon clone. Animations don't look like a Nintendo Switch game. Graphics, even for a Pokemon game, should be a lot better than they are. The elimination of the National Dex is something I learned to get over, but not being able to use GTS like in most previous titles leaves a lot to be desired from this game. Very underwhelmed.
titles: Hit and Miss, opinion changed upon further review

review_contents:
I have not fully beaten the game but i did make it to the third gym and a route beyond that and i was not expecting it to be this good :) with past games, u just simply go in the gyms and beat some trainers to get to the gym leader. This game still holds true to that but they added a gym challenge to spice things up. Gym challenges are certain objectives u have to do while you're also beating the trainers and its just so much fun and the scenery as u walk in is so breathtaking :) once u complete the challenge, the doors open and tons of people r cheering making u feel like actual pokemon trainer :D When the first gym leader dynamxed his pokemon, it makes things a bit tougher as it did way more damage than what i expected it to even though his pokemon isnt super effective against mine. That forced me to dynamax and set up defensive moves such as light screen and reflect and held up just in time for the 3 turns to be over and his pokemon reversed back to being tiny. I ended up beating the gym with red hp. The second gym was easy to beat since i had an electric type corgi and the 3rd gym gave me a bit of a challenge since i didnt have any pokemon with type advantages but still managed to win my second time around :)

This game has more freedom to roam around when ur done interacting with the main characters and theres lots of hidden stuff on the roads that shine as ur passing through. The diversity of old and new pokemon is outstanding as well. Theres lots of pokemon to choose from in every route. Even in the beginning of ur journey, u can start fishing with ur fishing rod so u can mix and match the perfect team from the start :) i would also advise being very careful in the wild area because i got my butt kicked with a level 45 Galvantula while i was just level 12. I was lucky to escape with my last pokemon still unfainted xD i was dumb enough to interact with it since i thought i would be lucky enough to catch it but found out u have to beat a certain amount of gyms in order to catch high level pokemon or else it'll just tell u that it wont let its guard down. Its the same concept as having a certain amount of gym badges to make high level pokemon from trades obey u. I had to find out the hard way lol

Now for the designs of the new pokemon and graphics of the games. Everyone has their own opinions on this ever since it was announced that there was gonna be no national dex. Personally, i avoided the leaks so idk what im expecting to get. So far, i love every single pokemon i have come across. Some r weird and funny looking but they do grow on u as u figure out they are really good in battles :) when they evolved, i still love the designs and was so surprised of the typings that were added and became even more useful to keep in ur team. It is true that many battle move animations and models r reused from past games but it really shouldnt matter all that much as alot of old moves have new animations and the pokemon's colors and textures look way better than the previous generations. The graphics in the wild area is the best ive seen except for the trees. The weird part is, the berry trees in the wild area look completely fine and fit well with the good graphics so my guess is that the company didnt really bother making those normal trees look as good since u cant interact with them at all and in my opinion thats completely fine. The graphics in the towns, caves, and routes are completely breathtaking so theres nothing negative i can say there :)

Despite lack of national dex i will say this. Overall, this game deserves its 5 stars and worth every penny. The variety of pokemon, the fun battles, and both ur awesome and jerk rivals make it a really fun experience for both oldschool and new trainers to enjoy. As i stated, i avoided every single thing about this game besides the announcement trailers from pokemon and nintendo so i was nervous since so many people were stating that the animations were garbage. Playing this game, i just dont see anything wrong with how it looks and how the pokemon move. The game and its scenery looks absolutely beautiful. I really recommend this game to at least be given a chance. I know it will be worth the gameplay :)

No national dex
No end game content
No story in between gyms
You just go from town to town getting badges. This is the worst pokemon game I have ever played. Skip this one. It's like the devs put so much focus into making the game look good, that they forgot to give us stuff to do.

I want to start off by clarifying that this is not a perfect game. No game is perfect, but faults are part of what makes something interesting. However, Pokemon Sword deserves these five stars. I haven‚Äôt finished the game, but so far I have been delighted, and it has met and exceeded my expectations. And that‚Äôs really all anyone could ask for. Could all of that change by the time I‚Äôve finished? Yes. But I don‚Äôt anticipate that happening.

I have played every main series Pokemon game since I got Pokemon Blue when I turned seven. Some games have been better than others; however, Pokemon Sword is settling in right there at the top. The game looks amazing; the new monsters are some of my favorites in years; the new Galar region is hands down the most immersive region so far; and the story is there, and I‚Äôm probably about halfway through, and I haven‚Äôt predicted the whole thing yet, so that‚Äôs great (although, I believe playing Pokemon for the story is like . . . well . . . you just don‚Äôt play Pokemon for the story)!

Pokemon Sword seems to have been very carefully thought out, and it takes everything that‚Äôs great about Pokemon and builds on it. Pokemon has always been about exploring new places, meeting new friends, and looking at the bright side, all while fighting for the glory of becoming the Champion and beating the bad guys! Pokemon Sword does all these wonderfully. And, while it‚Äôs a little cheesy, I have never felt so epic walking into a gym battle than I do in this game!

Now to address the almighty controversy of the missing National Pokedex. Yes, it‚Äôs gone. Do I miss it? A little. There are definitely some Pokemon I‚Äôm bummed I can‚Äôt use in this game, but let‚Äôs be real. You can only have six Pokemon in your party anyway. There are more than enough great Pokemon to choose from, and I will be even happier to see my favorites when they come back. And at the rate they‚Äôve been putting out Pokemon games lately, that probably won‚Äôt be too far in the future. They were right when they said that limiting Pokemon would have to happen eventually. I don‚Äôt care if they have all the storage space in the world to work from, or every single Pokemon is perfectly pre-designed and ready to pop in the game. Having that many options is overwhelming. The last time I caught every single Pokemon in a Pokemon game was in Pokemon X, and I‚Äôm still trying to decide if catching ‚Äòem all was an enjoyable experience or not. And yeah, for those who have favorite Pokemon they‚Äôve been training and carrying with them from game to game and suddenly can‚Äôt use them, that does suck. But it‚Äôs not like those Pokemon have been erased. They‚Äôre still useful in previous games, and they‚Äôll be again in future games. Pokemon Sword is simply a chance to try something new!

In short, I know my nephews (ages 6-12) will love this game! I really enjoy it too! Pokemon has always been, and should always be, designed for children. And they‚Äôve nailed it this time. It can‚Äôt be designed for everyone. That‚Äôs a bad business strategy. I'm just glad I get to join in on the fun!
Really gamefreak?

It pains me to write this because I was so looking forward to this game and I spent more than half my play time trying to convince myself I was loving it. But at some point we need to be honest with ourselves.

This game has no content. It's like someone built the skeleton of a Pokemon game but forgot to add the meat. Remember the old games where you had to overcome some obstacle to make it to a new city? A winding cave? A twisting forest? Or perhaps you had to complete a side objective before the gym leader would face you--Stopping Team Rocket in some scheme or finding a solution to a problem plaguing the town? Gone. All of that is gone. The game is quite literally just a series of linear hallway "routes" funneling you from one gym battle to the next. And since the game has been stripped of all its side content, contests and casinos and quests and the like, there's nothing to do in each city other than find the couple NPCs who will give you a free item. That's it. No reason to hang around, nothing barring you from proceeding.

And then there's the difficulty. Or the lack thereof. I read a review claiming this was the most difficult Pokemon game yet. I know not what that reviewer was smoking. The game throws so many pokemon at you so quickly that I had caught over 30 before I hit the first gym. Which meant I had a full team of six with diverse type coverage. And the automatic Exp. All means you will never have an underleveled team. I never came close to wiping out once and I beat the last several gyms with only one Pokemon, one-shotting everything that was thrown at me. All without ever grinding for even a minute.

I could go on about the story and such as some reviewers do, or address the smaller Pokedex (which personally I was fine with) but they seem irrelevant next to such sparse gameplay. It is a game, after all, which means the playing of it should be the highest priority. And I cannot recommend this game to anyone but the youngest, brand-newest Pokemon fans looking for the easiest possible entry into the series. But if you're an established player, or perhaps a potential new fan looking to give the series a spin now that it's on shiny modern hardware, move along. The game simply has nothing to offer beyond full 3d models. Which admittedly is a lot of fun and is the reason I am willing to give 2 stars rather than 1, in addition to the fact that it is technically a fully functional game, unlike many titles released these days.
titles: This game makes me sad at what could have been.

review_contents: I've watched many of the trailers prior to the release of the game and they got the excitement up for me. I've been a pokemon fan for as long as I can remember, and there haven't been titles that disappoint me too badly. Well obviously this being the first proper pokemon title for switch, it doesn't disappoint whatsoever. The character animations are great inside and outside of battle. Graphics look as crisp as ever. Having pokemon in the overworld is a nice touch to bring over from pokemon let's go. So far so good. And I'm sure after I'm further into the story I'll be able to tell more about it, but for now just the basic.

Missing almost half the roster of pokemon. Literally the catch phrase for over 20 years has been gotta catch em all and I cant even get a squirtle or bulbasaur. The new starters are pretty lame as well. A rabbit, a monkey or a crying lizard. Weak sauce.
titles: Pretty game but too many missing pokemon.

review_contents: Mainly writing this review because I'm sad to see these games get so much flack. Maybe it's my own opinion, but as someone who has played pokemon since the original yellow version, I really enjoyed this game. I think the graphics and soundtrack are beautiful and I enjoy exploring the world and locations a lot. It took me just as long to complete the main storyline for this game as it did for pretty much any other predecessor pokemon game, and the storyline plays out like most main title pokemon games, which I dont particularly mind. I absolutely loved the gym battles and found them exciting. The characters are colorful and the camping feature is a fun way to bond with pokemon. In terms of the main issue that majority people seem to have with this game, yes, I am sad that not all the pokemon are there and that even my absolute faves arent in here. However, I think that plays more into the sentiment most of us long term players have with pokemon we've carried with us throughout generations. Taking these games as they are, theyre fun and beautiful. I would like to see a little more out of the towns than most of them just being gym locations, however I can genuinely say I have a lot of fun with this game and I dont regret getting it.

Wow this game is one of the best pokemon games I've played. Love the graphics, the new region, the new mechanics and pokemon. I give it a 9/10 the only thing I'd love is 100% full control of the open world camera but I've played 1hr so far I 100% recommend and I did get to play sun and moon so I'm happy to get back in pokemon and this game did it.

I haven't felt this sense of wonder in a Pokemon game since the original red and blue. That was 25 years ago, and I remember receiving a GameBoy Color and Pokemon red and blue for my birthday. Discovering the world of Pokemon at the time was amazing. Future games were great too, but your first time only happens once. Somehow, this game made that happen again for me.

Positives:
+The story is interesting (although your rival can get in the way of it sometimes)
+The Dynamax/Gigantamax system is much more interesting that I thought it would be from previews. Dynamax actually works to make multiplayer more fun as well and isn't the overpowered gimmick I anticipated.
+Animations are beautiful
+There are a lot of nice quality of life improvements that the game lets you access immediately or very early in the story. These include a character that can really run, a bike, access to your stored boxes almost anywhere, and on-the-go online functions like trading and battling that don't require you to be anywhere specific.
+The new Wild Areas revolutionize the series and are an important part of the game. I absolutely love the Wild Area and the ability to sandbox in it to my heart's content. Camping, playing and interacting with your party, and the curry minigame are also interesting additions.
+That childish sense of wonder the game instills is also a huge positive for me. I'm not the sort to spoil myself with all the new pokemon, so each new pokemon I run into has been a nice surprise where I still need to figure out their type.
+There is an endgame.
+The music! There is a Celtic theme in part of the Wild Area that is my favorite.

There are a few negatives to mention:
-Servers seem fairly unstable at the moment, although I hope this will be fixed in time.
-There are some framerate stutters in the Wild Areas and in some Max Raid battles. It is definitely worse when playing online, perhaps due to how the game pops other players in and out seemingly at random.
-My final gripe is one with the series in general, and that's not being able to customize my character to be more of an adult. With all the clothing, hair, eye, and skin tone options, this would be an easy addition, and a huge gift to fans who started this series as children and still play as adults.
-I don't think I can write a review about this game without mentioning the National Dex controversy. Yes, most of my favorite Pokemon are now missing in action. As I've played, however, this has become a non-issue and I have found others that I am familiar with or new ones to love. We've also been told that future games will probably have Dex limitations as well, but that currently excluded Pokemon will be present in those. In the end, it wasn't the dealbreaker or problem that I think the internet made it out to be.

I would always welcome (much) higher difficulty and adult trainer options, but it's a great game and the best in the series in my opinion. 9.2 out of 10.
titles: The Pokemon game I've waited 25 years for...

review_contents:
If you're reading this, you're probably already aware of just how polarizing Sword and Shield were upon release. I have never judged a book by its cover and am always willing to try something out before formulating a solid opinion, but this game is just... it's a lot of things. I kept my pre-order up despite being skeptical with each new trailer, and I hate to say that I ended up feeling less than satisfied with just about every aspect of this game. I want to get into why I feel like Pokemon Sword and Shield just aren't worth your money.

Pokemon games have always been formulaic and targeted at a younger audience, and that's perfectly fine. When your base game works well, why change it? Instead, expand on ideas, content, and mechanics to keep things fresh and engaging. If you can't build up, build out! That's not the case here. For the first mainline game on Switch, playing it felt hollow and empty. The routes between cities and towns are basically straight lines with only a few trainers and nothing to explore. The Wild Area is honestly quite good and mostly well-executed, but the performance issues are glaring. Once you comb through the Wild Area, that's basically all of the exploration and discovery the game has to offer. The Story is a dumpster fire of adults telling you "Nah bro, just go to the next gym, we'll handle the threat." and the handholding is a little excessive.

I stretched out my playtime by talking to every npc, frequently setting up camp, returning to the Wild Area after every gym, and playing around with my trainer outfit. But there's just not a lot of content here. The game is excruciatingly short, only padded by the various times npcs stop you dead in your tracks to tell you something you already know. I'm not going to go into detail about the reused models and cut Pokemon, but both of those are a huge blow to this game, and only make me feel worse when I think about it. Pocket Monsters has had the slogan "Gotta Catch 'em All" since the beginning, and as the biggest media franchise in the world? Cutting a chunk of them out feels incredibly lazy, not to mention insulting, after the fans were lied to about the reasons for cutting said Pokemon.

To set the record straight, I love that this is the first Pokemon game that people have played with their kids, and that they genuinely enjoy it. While I feel that this game isn't worth the 60$ I paid for it, I'm seriously happy that people are having fun. That's the point of video games-- to have fun. The Switch is a great console for families and I'm glad that its bringing people together to dive into the franchise. That being said, I'll go ahead and talk about some things that I liked about the game.

The graphics looks nice. Aside from the pop-in, mismatched trees, and lazy animations, the overall look of the game is innocent, cartooney, vibrant, and a little nostalgic. Overall, it does look nice and I really love the color palette. I also really like the new evolution methods for certain Pokemon, they were cryptic but clever, and it was fun trying to figure out the trick to evolving certain ones. Lastly, I do really like the new Pokemon designs! While I understand it's subjective, I felt that the new roster was very solid and diverse. Also, I do actually like the Pokemon Camp feature, it just needs some tweaking.

With the Expansion Passes on the horizon, I sadly just can't say that I'm confident. It's too little too late. Even if the expansions are really good, paying for that on top of a 60$ half-baked game just makes me feel depressed.

I can't really recommend this.

If you are a competitive battler, here's your review.
If you okay with an incomplete pokedex, and you only care about destroying your opponents with the pokemon allotted to you, then Sw/Sh is your game. The meta is fairly balanced as far as I can tell, and training up competitive pokemon is easier than ever, which was something I never thought would be possible back in 2016. You may be dismayed to find that not all of the attacks made it from previous games into this one.

If you have every single pokemon memorized, here's your review.
You won't be seeing half of them, so wait a year for the majority of the other half to be patched into the game. Until then, enjoy the new gen 8 pokemon if you can.

If you want to see all of your old pokemon from Sun and Moon moved over into HD glory, please beware:
You have to pay for two services, pokemon bank and pokemon home. Bank is 5 USD per year, and Home has a month long subscription, and a year long subscription. But here's where things can get ugly for you. Say you have a shiny garchomp in pokemon Sun. You move it to bank then move it again into pokemon home, because home can accommodate any pokemon with any move. You then learn that your garchomp has a move that doesn't exist in pokemon Sword, so now you have this pokemon that can't be moved back into pokemon bank and can't be moved into sword. That hypothetical situation actually isn't hypothetical at all. Option one: I continue paying for pokemon home so my garchomp doesn't get obliterated into a billion randomized 1s and 0s, or Option two: I stop giving Game Freak my money and watch my garchomp, rayquaza and Articuno from my LeafGreen game get obliterated. My word of advice to you would be: Research before exporting your pokemon to Home. What a scummy business practice.

If you like some good gameplay, here's your review.
You can get the same battle system but better in Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire. All of the mega evolutions are available, your roster is way bigger, but training up a good team is way harder and breeding is required (or Homebrew). Basically, the gameplay in generation 8 is copied and pasted from the previous games, but without mega evolutions and no Z moves.

If you like a good storyline, here's your review.
Your storyline consists of moving from town to town while being directed to the next town by Hop, the tour guide. The villain's intentions are unclear, no food for thought at any point in time. You'd be better off reading a Magic Tree House book than buying this game for some storyline.

And if you're the guy who plays Doom Eternal on PC at max settings 144 fps.
Don't buy this game.
titles: RUSHED, and I will tell you why.

review_contents:
I am in my late 20's and grew up playing Pokemon games. I have more than half of the pokemon games which have been released. When I read some bad reviews I refused to believe this game could be that bad, but nope, they were right, it really is terrible. In this game the dialog is awful, cheesy, and clearly was designed for little kids. For me it feels like a joke and as if they didn't try at all and knew people would buy it anyways. I read another review on here where someone said the graphics were garbage and I would have to agree. I hate this new style of graphics and even the way they made the battles look. I can't imagine how I will finish this game, but I will try to get at least halfway through it and then come back to edit my review.

Pros
There are alot of new pokemon which is cool, but alot of them seem lame to be honest.
If you are buying this game for a small child then it might be worth it, but wow, this game drops the ball in so many ways. I hope you don't feel like it was a waste of money like I do.
titles: Never Written a bad Review on any Pokemon Product, Until Now

review_contents:
This game doesn't come close to the content and quality of previous pokemon games. It is slow, tedious and leaves you bewildered with the "Is that it???" feeling. Pokemon Sun/Moon, Let's Go and Pokemon Go are much more fun.

I dosed off during the Gigantamax battles. You don't even know what the battles are for until the game is over making the exercise pointless. They are stronger Pokemon but you already finished the game before you get to see the Pokemon's strength. So you make your pokemon stronger for what? The game is long over.

What is shocking is that this is about the same price as Breath of the Wild which can entertain for months on end.

Pokemon Sword is just a grind without the challenges of previous Pokemon games.
titles: Way too expensive for what it is.  Doesn't live up to the Pokemon brand.

review_contents: There is no game card inside the box. So upset with it.

This is not a new pokemon franchise game, it's Sun and Moon with new cosmetics. The gameplay has had no significant changes and there is no enthralling story to keep one from knit-picking at such details. Even without considering the drama around Dexit, this game is not what I signed up for, and I'm extremely disappointed in the product, double considering the price. This plays like a $3 used 3DS game.
titles: Returned the game without playing after seeing playthroughs.

review_contents: I was one of the hardcore Pokemon faithful thinking this game was going to be the Holy Grail of the home console Pokemon games. I started out playing Pokemon Red on the GBC back in the day and this game is the total opposite. Pokemon Sword lacks depth in gameplay, challenges, and Pokemon. I straight finished the story in under thirty hours. The lack of challenges is noticeable because the game just tells you where to go. Their is no more having to find the move to train your Pokemon to cut down trees, strength to move boulders, or swimming to get across the river. This game just hands it to you and there is no challenge whatsoever. Heck whatever starter Pokemon you pick you'll be 99% of the game one shot dropping opponents Pokemon all the time. The difficulty is this game is severely lacking. This game is straight garbage can juice and avoid it as much as possible. Rent it if you really want to play it but, do not buy. This game has great graphics, awesome sound, and dynamax Pokemon. That's all it has going for it.

This game is a great new entry to the series. Is it perfect? No. Could they add more, sure. Is it incredibly enjoyable, beautiful, approachable and chock full of Pok√©mon adventures?? Yes, yes and yes. Go catch em all.
titles: The game is great, internet needs to chill.

review_contents:
After some initial issues with delivery (lost package?) We finally recieved the product. The game is easily worth a good solid 40hours of game play by story alone. Followed by online tournaments, and battles. This holds true with the partner version as well.

The ability to collect and add to your collection is great. As new expansions for these games will be coming available alone with home. Which will allow you to take old games and import your Pokemon into the newest versions.

It's will be the first Pokemon game to receive expansions in the coming months.

It features breeding, Pokemon go style raids, access for those with poke ball plus, training and interacting with your Pokemon via camping (love seeing my Arcanine bounce happily, and send me his thoughts during battles.)

The personalities they have given Pokemon have been improved over earlier generations. So some may even resist feigning just because they don't want you to be sad.. (aww... ). So you can't help but fall in love with the little darlings.

You can send them off on jobs as well. Which I think is pretty neat.

While it does lack access to the mini-games like in older versions casino, Megamall shopping, etc. It still does have a lottery system.

I do believe they will be expanding on the current amount of Pokemon in the game with future patches and expansions. Can't wait :)

First of all I wasn‚Äôt planning of getting this, I thought I‚Äôd hate them but the games are actually decent and date I say good in some areas, the problem is clear by the 3rd last gym, this games were rushed, and that‚Äôs a shame cause I can see care and quality in parts of the game, game freak is not lazy cause I can see care in some details the galar region is beautiful, but this games are far from perfect, things I disliked outside the textures of some things like the trees are: the gold your hand real thigh theres always a character telling you were to go and what to do, there are scenes that something is going on off screen and by the time you get there is over and the characters tell you what happened, don‚Äôt tell me show me, there‚Äôs no way to turn off the exp share and that to me is super annoying, Pok√©mon get over power easily and personally I do not like that, I like to train my Pok√©mon individually, luckily to fix this you can access your box without being in a poke center, I actually am enjoying the story so far but I can clearly tell how they went wrong, is not game freaks fault is the Pok√©mon company‚Äôs, the price are high and I thing thats bad they should‚Äôve offered something to justify the price for a half baked game.
Very happy can't wait to play this game!!!!!üòÅ

It's not a bad game, but it's not a great game. Most fans of the series will get a good amount of enjoyment out of this game, but not without wishing there was a bit more or that some features worked better. The character models look incredible, but a lot of the battle animations are pretty basic. Doesn't seem to be as many unique NPCs in this game as there were in previous games, but that probably won't bother too many. The main story in recent games always seemed to go by very fast, no exception with these two new games. The Pokedex is pretty small and easy to complete. I do wish they at least included a bit more Pokemon in the dex. I'm sure most fans will find at least a few 'mon they wish were included in these games. The online mode is a bit hit or miss. The game noticeably stutters while playing online in the "Wild Area" and the Y-link system for finding online raids doesn't consistently work. Hopefully online play will see some improvements soon. I've put over 100 hours into this game and will probably put in a good bit more over the coming weeks. I really do hope Gamefreak takes some of the earnings from these games and hires some more employees so they can make the next Pokemon game a masterpiece.
titles: It's not bad, but it's not great.  Still having some fun with it.  Online play needs improvements.

review_contents:
I know that Sword and Shield are pretty controversial, but they're great games and solid additions to the franchise, and they don't deserve all this negativity.
Sure, I feel like a lot of anger towards the games are justified, don't get me wrong. The cut of about half of all pokemon was pretty brutal and not really necessary, and it also meant the cut of many of my top favorites--most starters, most legendaries, and so on. Furthermore, most animations as well as models were simply reused from Gen. VII, despite what the creators claimed. These are all valid reasons to be angry, and as someone who has loved Pokemon since Gen. III, I am disappointed.
BUT. Even so, these games do not deserve the hate! They are good, fun games. The cities look amazing and the music is great. There's so many cool new pokemon and the Galar region is brimming with character. I enjoyed playing these games. They may not be my absolute favorites in the franchise, but they were really, really fun, and I look forward to seeing what GameFreak has for us in the future.

Unlike a lot of the reviews you read, I actually beat the game before writing. I‚Äôve been playing since the originals came out when I was in middle school. I‚Äôm not a hardcore Pok√©mon fanboy or anything, but I enjoy playing the games. This game has streamlined many issues that have plagued the games for years. The wild area is a great addition, the gym battles are fantastic. They give you a great feeling of actually accomplishing something at the end. The end game is full of extra things to do. The low reviews are only National dex fanboys who are angry that they can‚Äôt play with some made up character they caught in a game when they were 7. Bottom line, sword is a fantastic game, and was a pleasure to play.

Despite a couple nuances like the omission of a good chunk of the Pok√©dex and a relatively small map (somewhat between Kalos and Alola‚Äôs size), the new installment offers a surprisingly exciting catalogue of new Pok√©mon and strategy. The new mechanics, like the dreadful permanent exp share, has been rebalancd to a point where I never felt I was over leveled past the second gym, and the extra exp offered me the opportunity to be more experimental with my team build up, allowing me to try new Pok√©mon on the fly, rotating members into my team without fear of insanely intense grinding sessions. And with the new features that make egg move sharing and nature changes possible, alongside the recently previously stablished IV EV training and maxing of any Pok√©mon, I finally feel like I can stick to the Pok√©mon I‚Äôve come to love and raise since the start of my adventure with incredibly little compromise into the competitive online scene.
Es muy divertido pero Me ofende que siendo el pokemon mas caro los pokemon no tengan mas animaciones como Gamefreak lo prometi√≥. Al menos es mejor que Pokemon Lets Go,

Pros and cons:

Cons -
* There is too much hand holding, your friends keep healing you before you get to the next Pokemon center.
* Your rival Hop picks the weakest typing to yours why? Because Gamefreak's new way of thinking is why.
* There are too many occasions where you are forced into double battles with Hop when I didn't ask for it. Couldn't double battles be saved for end-game content not away too make beating the story a breeze please.
* I cannot transfer Typhlosion or Lugia.
* holding back Pokemon that Gamefreak said previously for reasons you cannot put them in the game at first it was understood, but It would seem that your true intions was too lie in order to sell them back to us because you think you can get away with it. (of course you can, your Gamefreak). NOT COOL GAMEFREAK!
* saving the best for last the creation of team yell I've talked with other fans who agree with me and they think that team yell is a waste of space. They might as well have created Pokemon Sword and Shield without an evil team. They wern't even evil, more like either confused or they just served to get in your way without a cause. That is team yell is problem. They are just a reskin of team skull which even though I felt like I couldn't take them seriously many times they at least had a cause under Guzma. So far the best evil teams in my opinion are team rocket and team flare. I miss the old days. They probably made team yell this way so they wouldn't have too delay the game.

Pros:
* It's a very pretty game but it is in no way leap in graphics based off of the Switch's own hardware because they used the 3DS engine and just enhanced it. I am willing too admit it's pretty.
* The wild area is expansive. It felt like a first-time open world Pokemon game so I'll give Gamefreak some credit for this idea but the trees do look like N64 trees.
* Dynamax battles and Pokemon are a challenge to catch them I especially found that to be true with Dynamax Machamp. But the gyms are too damn easy.
* League cards and pokejobs are cool.

Originally I was going to be a proud boycotter and refuse to play the game but I didn't want to regurgitate what others are saying because if someone asked me if I played it then my answer would be ridiculous and uncredible. So I bought it used. Was it worth it? While I did have fun team yell and Hop were the most annoying parts of the game to be fair for now I will probably say the jury is still out on this one. I can't say for sure I do still play the game I like customizing my avatar I do intend to buy the DLC. Based on the way Gamefreak treated this game I don't feel like their team deserves praise for it or money so I recommend that you buy it used if your interested. I expect quality over quantity.
titles: It's a pretty game but not stunning.

review_contents:
I wouldn‚Äôt call myself a hardcore Pok√©mon fan, but definitely consider myself a fan. I‚Äôve played nearly every generation so far except 2, 4, and 7, but will get around to doing so. Sword is imo one of my favorites in the franchise. The game itself ran well for me. I had a fun time playing it and I think the new Pok√©mon from the Galar region were for the most part well designed. The game at its core is still the same old Pok√©mon. You catch Pok√©mon, battle trainers, compete against gyms, save the world, and become champion.

Graphically, the game looks really good. The Galar region was one of my favorites to adventure across. One thing I particular liked with this game was big wild areas where Pok√©mon an abundance of Pok√©mon ran free for you to catch or battle. Plus I liked how the tall grass functioned where you could slowly sneak through it, see the Pok√©mon, and if you ran through it, startled unseen Pok√©mon. I thought this was a cool change. I was playing through Yellow on the 3DS prior to this game and I definitely do not miss how the tall grass worked in previous games. Another new feature is ‚Äúdynamax‚Äù and ‚Äúgigantamax‚Äù. This essentially replaces mega evolution and I think it‚Äôs much better. Mega evolution was too OP and while dynamaxing can be, it‚Äôs only available in certain battles, but it‚Äôs a very cool feature and certain Pok√©mon even take on a new appearance if capable of gigantamaxing.

Now obviously one of the cons to newer Pok√©mon games is they‚Äôre easier. While I agree with this, it‚Äôs not a dealbreaker. I like EXP share, I like that HMs are no more. While these things have certainly made battles easier, it‚Äôs made the games much more convenient and less of a grind to play.

All in all, this was another enjoyable Pok√©mon experience for me and I‚Äôd put Sword up there as one of my favorites in the franchise and I look forward to the two expansions.
titles: A Fun Addition to the Franchise

review_contents: This game is basically the developer taking the same old crumbling house and slapping a brand new coat of paint on, the attaching a shed to the back door calling it a brand new game. The laziness is littered everywhere and there‚Äôs literally nothing interesting or fun about this game.
