The older Pok√©mon was fun because of its simplicity and straightforwardness, and this game isn‚Äôt because it added complexity that is not fun nor interesting, all the while skipping a ton of content to meet release deadline. Do yourself a favor and do not reward Nintendo for this ill conceived game.
titles: Lazy title from a lazy developer

review_contents:
I gave this game 5 stars because of the amount of fun I got out of it (it's my 3rd most played Pokemon generation and we don't even have the DLC yet).

I will refrain from spoiling contents of the game and simply say what was done well/not well.

There are many good and bad things about the game:

PROS:
-Beginning of game was average pace in my opinion (not too slow/heavy on hand-holding)
-It's on the Switch (play anywhere/anytime; I loved playing Pokemon on the big screen)
-Gym Leader battles are awesome (I recommend battling with surround sound if you get the chance)
-Good for beginners; the game does not introduce an overwhelming amount of Pokemon/mechanics
-Training competitively viable Pokemon is now easier than ever
-Fun to play with friends; requires interacting with other people to complete Pokedex
-Completing Pokedex (400 species) does not take very long (my save file was at about 90 hours, and I did most of it myself/took my time) as long as you use friends/internet
-Music was great
-Graphics were fine for a Pokemon game, I personally wasn't bothered by frame drops or anything (which especially happen if you are connected to the internet)
-Character customizability is nice
-Post-game content is average at best, but the DLC this year will makes it way way better
-Rare Pokemon (shinies/6 IV/etc.) are easier to acquire because raids are multiplayer activities, so friends can share the raid of the Pokemon with friends (and breeding is very fast)
-Wild Area isn't massive, but it's fun (and DLC will add more)
-Some quality of life improvements (like exp. candies)
-Constant local connection unless you switch to airplane mode (probably saves on battery life/heat tbh)
-Dynamax concept seems lame, but it is mechanically surprisingly fun in my opinion

CONS:
-Story was not the most captivating (many plot points seemed poorly planned out)
-Rare Pokemon (shinies/6 IV/etc.) are easier to acquire because raids are multiplayer activities, so those Pokemon don't feel quite as special
-I want Gen III Battle Frontier, but I know I'm the minority
-Small thing: I know ghost/psychic types have always been in Pokemon and their subjects are popular in Japan, but I was still troubled when I came across an in-game add for a job that was requesting help from Ghost-type pokemon for advertising occult books. It was just a textual reference, but the use of the term "occult" made it pretty explicit. Spiritual entities aren't uncommon concepts, but as a Catholic I would prefer that games not make light of subjects with grave moral/spiritual implications. Again, I know it's partly Japanese culture, and Pokemon games/shows have always had some references to occult (similar to "that fortune teller episode" in Avatar: The Last Airbender), so just be ready to exercise some intellect and faith if you have younger children that you want to enjoy Pokemon without being malformed/getting the wrong idea (which you should be doing for pretty much everything they do anyways).

Looking forward to the DLC.
titles: First time I caught 'em all since Gen I

review_contents:
Pokemon Sword and Shield finally come to home consoles. Ignoring that it's missing more than half of the Pokedex; the game is still just the same Pokemon you've been playing for decades now. Very few new things are brought to the table and anything newly implemented is half-hearted.

Everything about this titles feels incredibly rushed. Hopes are high at first when you're plopped down relatively quickly into the open-world-esque environment, your dreams get dashed almost immediately when you see how terrible it all looks. Graphically, this game is hideous. Poor textures, lowly detailed open-world environments look bland; complete with horrible pop-in. I have reason to believe the New 3DS was capable of the same graphical fidelity.

Story has never been a strong point for the Pokemon series but it's never been this bad! By the time the end credits rolled, I continued pressing 'A' as if I was just trying to get through another boring random battle. As normal, AI is brain-dead and other trainers use no specific tactic to even try to challenge it's players. Online connectivity is horrible and confusing. Even something as simple as just trading with a local friend is like jumping through hoops. The raid battle are laughable and a good portion of them can be done with the AI.

This is just a trimmed down version of Pokemon really. It's not better or worse in terms of combat. The gimmick for this Pokemon entry is making your Pokemon really big and they have flashy move-sets that look really cool. But by the time you're just a few gym badges in, you realize this is nothing more than flash. Most of the time, it's a complete waste of time to even Dynamax your Pokemon. You could have simply mutilated your opponent with the amount of time it takes to watch the animation of your Pokemon becoming a behemoth.

If you love Pokemon, you'll probably still get entertainment from these titles, but me? I bow out, until the developers can show me some innovation. This is NOT the Pokemon console game we wanted...but it is just more Pokemon.

Most irritatingly the game is lacking 52% of all pokemon.

Now if that's not enough to detour you from considering this game, I went ahead and finished it just so that I may give you an adequate review.

The game adds some cool features like Dynamaxing pokemon, where your pokemon basically become gigantic and gain super moves for 3 turns. My Zigzagoon became gigantic and that kind of sold the function for me. Its a ton of fun being able to make any 1 pokemon strong for 3 turns.

Its like a lazy version of mega pokemon, the low turn rate on the gigantimax forms just makes it feel like some temporary gimmick.

Beyond that, they have this big world zone where people are supposed to be able to interact to cooperate in order to catch gigantic pokemon.

Online functionality really sucked because it seemingly never found anyone to play with and consequently I had to team up with the random NPCs that they offered.

I really enjoyed the wonder trades of previous games, this one takes forever to find trade partners.

I needed to trade with a real life friend of mine who was quite literally across from me in the room. Rather than being able to trade wirelessly like previous games, it insisted that I connect to online. After doing so, they offered no function to invite my friend directly to trade, instead I had to do this dumb 4 digit number code. My friend then matched my code and hoped that we would be paired as trading partners. One time I was matched with some random person online while expecting to trade with my friend, this in particular frustrated me considerably.

Also its worth noting that, of all the times for my Nintendo Online subscription to run out, it was on that specific day.

So you will need Nintendo Online if you wish to trade pokemon....yup.

As a story, this game gets up to the Elite Four equivalent and then basically just has this stupid detour where you have to do a bunch of other things. I found this very irritating because by this point I just wanted to complete the game and instead it dragged me to a lot of other random crap. I wanted the game to end, I was legitimately bored after the 4th badge.

I actually enjoyed the new characters and region within this game, and the new pokemon were actually pretty cool.

With all of that being said, I would've played this game regardless because it is a pokemon main series game.

Sun/Moon was previously my least favorite within the series. Sun/Moon however offers more to do as well as the remaining 52% of pokemon and mega evolutions with significantly better online functionality.
titles: It's pokemon, so ofc I will play it.

review_contents: So glad I pre-ordered this back in June! Great game! Awesome graphics!

Sword and Shield are the newest editions to the Pok√©mon franchise with both some welcome changes and some annoying ones.

Story:
SwSh are the most linear Pok√©mon games to date. The characters are interesting but annoying. You‚Äôll be constantly interrupted in your adventure by your rivals who hold your hand through the entirety of the storyline. Sadly, there‚Äôs little room to deviate from the intended plot progression, which makes it feel less like exploring a world and more like reading a book.

Post game:
There isn‚Äôt really much of a post game plot. There are multiplayer and battle tower options. Because of GF‚Äôs decision to eliminate the National dex, the ranked battles have very little variety of Pok√©mon, making it pretty boring. The battle tower isn‚Äôt new but is fun.

Mechanics changes:
No more HMs, no national dex, GTS is gone, multiplayer is revamped, making your Pok√©mon gigantic is now a thing. Most of these changes are okay. The lack of the GTS makes trading difficult online, especially since there isn‚Äôt a way to communicate with other players. The raid co-op invitations only work some of the time, both connected to the internet and local. The graphics aren‚Äôt a huge leap forward and are still lagging behind many other switch games. One area in the game allows rotating the camera, which is both new and welcome.

Overall impressions:
The new Pok√©mon designs are pretty great and the characters aren‚Äôt flat. I didn‚Äôt really enjoy the story and the side plot didn‚Äôt really kick into gear until the story was nearly over. The post game is very weak and the game is quickly growing boring. I‚Äôd still buy again but this game is relatively boring when compared to other Pok√©mon generations.

Edit Jan 2020:
Pok√©mon recently announced they will sell extra downloadable content. It‚Äôs $30 per version but will offer two new areas, new plots, and 200+ more Pok√©mon than originally available. Hopefully this addresses the main issues with the post game and ranked battles.

I'm an advid fan of pokemon games and wanted to like this so so bad, but it's so darn boring!! The graphics are ok but theres way to many cut scenes and not enough pokemon time. I'm five hours in and feel like I've barely started. Very disappointed :,(

It's a Pokemon game... you know what you're getting. A few tweeks to the story (yes, there is a story other than "collect the 8 things to challenge some slightly stronger people") make it a decent game.

I'm not one to mind losing half the dex. There hasn't been a Pokemon game in over 10 years that actually let you catch every pokemon in the game anyways, so this doesn't really affect me or my opinion of this game.

The only actually thing I dislike about this game is that it doesn't feel like the second highest grossing video game franchise in history. It feels like a cheaper Chinese knock off. By no means does it always feel like this, but when compared to Odyssey or Breath of the Wild, it feels like they cheaped out a bit. Still very enjoyable, but you can see where they tried to save money.

If you dont care (or have the time) to catch all 1,000 pokemon, and dont mind the occasional trash graphics in non-battle areas, and like pokemon, you cant go wrong with this game! If, however, you're very upset that some 500 pokemon wont make it into a game where you wouldn't even be able to catch them in the game, just wait until the mid-generation refresh when they'll bring all the pokemon back (let's be real, the ONLY reason Gamefreak cut all the pokemon is because they want to play the good guy when they bring all the Pokemon back in Sword and Shield).

In short, the outrage over this game is overblown in my opinion. It's a fun game that offers the occasional challenge. Perfect for casual play. Here's hoping Gamefreak actually makes a proper AAA game next time, because this certainly isn't that.

Not super impressed with this game. First, there were no issues receiving or downloading the game, so my complaints are entirely to do with the game itself.

Game Freak simply didn‚Äôt change enough about the Pok√©mon formula with this game. That became apparent when I still had to sit through an hour or so of unskippable exposition to finally get to the real game, which itself felt like a carbon copy of every other Pok√©mon game I have ever played. Not to mention that the graphics and move animations were not up to par with the Switch‚Äôs capabilities. In fact, I didn‚Äôt really see much of a graphical difference between this and the 3ds games before it.

The graphics aren‚Äôt really a huge problem, but I don‚Äôt feel like I should be spending $60 on something so similar to the original games. Because that‚Äôs what it really comes down to: this game doesn‚Äôt have enough originality and novelty to make me feel good about my purchase.

I haven‚Äôt played the online part of this game, so I have no opinions either way regarding it.

Finally! A console pokemon game with a battle system that isn't milking the tit of Pokemon Go! The story was as good as you'd expect a Pokemon game story to get. Actually, in my opinion it was the second-best story (after X/Y). This game contains many quality of life improvements. It is now easier to fill your Pokedex as long as you want to pursue that. Leveling pokemon isn't hard at all. You get experience share from the beginning, and all of the raids drop experience candy that you can use on any pokemon. Super helpful if you got a pokemon and you just want to evolve it for the dex entry. Pop it an XL Exp candy and boom. Instant levels. The Pokedex event makes recommendations to you with 1-3 pokemon you can catch right then to fill out the dex, and shows you where you might find them. The daily weather system adds a lot of dynamics to the game, making it possible to only catch certain pokemon in that kind of weather.

But the best part of the experience is the Gym challenge. For the first time do you really feel like you are a pro taking on a league. Battles in a stadium. Walking out onto the turf. Fans cheering. Customizable trading cards. Epic music. This is the Pokemon game we all have been waiting for.
titles: The Pokemon we've been waiting for.

review_contents:
So, I‚Äôm writing this after beating the main storyline and putting 75+ hours into game play. Galar has some great new Pok√©mon, but there‚Äôs a few complaints: The main story is very simple (not overly engaging), the town to town gym battle left very little for exploration post-game (outside of the Wilds) and even while playing, and the Wilds was an amazing idea but it just feels like it is still in beta testing.

I would definitely still recommend this game (giving 4/5 stars) as it has a solid introduction of raid concepts (sort of transferred from Pok√©mon Go?), and the weather-based concept for catching Pok√©mon is interesting (but it encourages spoofing to get the weather you ‚Äúneed‚Äù), also endgame Battle Tower & hyper training is great for those beyond casual players.

If you‚Äôre still reading, go ahead and get it. But just know that some things will feel like a let down... but overall, there‚Äôs something exciting about a new Gen of Pok√©mon & starting the new era of Switch/Switch Lite games. I‚Äôm interested to see how Pok√©mon Go/Let‚Äôs Go/Sword&Shield will lead into Gen 9 or the revamp of Gen 8.

TL;DR: Solid intentions, but a story and formatting let down. But still very worth it for causal players, and experienced players will have to endure Game Freak‚Äôs first bumpy foray into Switch territory.
titles: First Switch-based Pok√©mon game has a few bumps

review_contents:
Hop just feeding himself to your team every corner, this game is a downgrade from switch let‚Äôs go titles, devs rushed so hard to get this out to tie in with series, story not enjoyable, rotom is a slave like animals in the Flintstone, music is lackluster and a lot of downtimes without audio of anything just eerie scenes with characters lips moving most of the time, dynamax is unbalanced, new legends don‚Äôt feel like legends/mythical only thing cool is the attack animation, story is like 4hrs if that even but walking here and there is like a chore of no other and takes 20-30hrs. the ‚ÄúAntagonist‚Äù is out to stop slavery by reinventing an ancient source of energy that could help the entire region but I cared so little about him, the region or the residents for such little effort went in with storytelling. I‚Äôm sure everyone and region will have full backstory in the anime series, but this game.. nope. Even the badguy reveals himself the very last moment and you take him on with ease. Only Hop, that is at your face every 5-15mins, has some character depth. The new dynamax feature I got to use very little throughout game. When you do use it the music fades out and feels like I‚Äôm waterlogged. So much is water-down, the gyms aren‚Äôt as exciting as they appear. After the third one you just want to finish them as quickly as possible. ‚ÄîThere‚Äôs even a joke about that from one of the npc trainers. The wild area isn‚Äôt as big as suggested. Camping is more like a sleeping/AFK feature than gameplay. Charizard isn‚Äôt that cool in this and they know it. Game is just rushed, not much care went in, copy and pasted, characters are just thrown in, just... a mess. But it‚Äôs pok√©mon, and they got away with it.. so they‚Äôll be another just like it. It‚Äôs like Let‚Äôs Go Pika/Eev graphics with 3DS gameplay (with all sprites lifted,) and even feels like sun/moon.

Pros: online is the best feature, clothing is sorta cute, the chants when dynamax, cooking is alright, made training a bit easier
titles: Hi, I‚Äôm Hop and this is the rest of crew I don‚Äôt even care

review_contents: I have been hyped for this game way to long and to finally own it is awesome. I am really enjoying the game it has stuff for everyone in it! I‚Äôm glad they added a lot more Pok√©mon from the previous Pok√©dex than I thought they were. I love this game and I‚Äôm only through the first gym. I recommend this game for new and old Pok√©mon fans. It does not disappoint.

To start off - I'm a casual Pokemon player, and I have been since Red and Blue. I don't EV/IV Train, I don't worry about competitive, and I don't make 'roid rage Clefables with meticulously crafted Effort Values and Movesets. If that's what you play these games for, I won't be much help.

I'm also not a picky consumer - much of the controversy surrounding this game is around the number of Pokemon from previous games that were "culled", and while I'm a bit bummed that some of my favorites aren't in the game, it doesn't offend my sensibilities and I don't feel like Nintendo or Gamefreak desecrated my familial burial site because of it. I bought this game with full knowledge that we were working with a smaller pool of Pokemon.

With that all being said:

- PRO: Gameplay on the Switch is fun. I've really loved watching the Pokemon series evolve with the systems they're on. The environments are gorgeous, and the world feels more lived in than usual.
- PRO: Wild Area, while it has its bugs, is overall a fantastic addition to the game. Seeing other players messing around and just having the access and ability to so many Pokemon so early in the game is great for me, someone who doesn't play competitive, as it gives me more options to use during my playthrough since I'm not concerned about much else.
- PRO: The music for the game is fantastic. The gym music really gets me hyped. It's everything 10 year old me dreamed of and more.
- PRO: Leveling seems to have been simplified and made easier for ease of use and accessibility. Some of you may hate it. For me, it's time I don't have to sink into superfluous crap. I'm here to game, not take a second job.
- CON: For a main line Pokemon game, this feels a bit...short. Maybe it's been too long since standard Sun and Moon and it's the same length it's always been, but to me at least, it seemed shorter than usual. This is exacerbated a little by the lack of "minigames" to me, as I spent a lot of time doing the surfing and other stuff in Sun/Moon. Again, I could 100% be forgetting if Sun and Moon was a little barren as its been a while and I had no major complaints
- CON: as a follow up to the last point, not much post game stuff. I think there's battle tower and you can replay a mini-gym challenge, but that seems to be about it.
- CON: this one's more of a personal gripe, but the catch rates on Gigantamaxed Pokemon is so abyssmal that you'll want to temper your expectations there. Rates on them are also absurdly low (to even encounter) so if you're someone who wants to collect every version of every thing, you might have a couple years of gameplay here.

Overall, I think this is a great game. It doesn't deviate from the formula, and if you like Pokemon games usually, you'll probably like this one.
titles: More of the Same, if that's your style.

review_contents: Bought a switch light just to play this game, after playing for 2 hours I went and sold everything back to GameStop. The game had been dumb down and made too easy. I love Pok√©mon and having been playing since blue but sadly this will be my last Pok√©mon game I will ever play and probably my last Nintendo purchase, I‚Äôm just done.

I enjoyed the story for what it is. Without spoiling anything, I'll say that it was enjoyable. Interesting change to the primary gimmick by making the gyms all compete with one another. I didn't feel too compelled to do any of the post-game content as I mostly enjoy catching new Pokemon and trying out new teams.

The multiplayer gimmick of fighting giant powered-up Pokemon in dens is both really fun and terrible. You can see a den on the list, select it, and then promptly be told that it's full or closed. Weirdly, this doesn't remove it from the list and there's few moments when it will refresh. So you could have a full list of dens and have none of them available.

Conversely, I've found that "unpopular" dens (an event Pokemon that outstays its welcome for example) will struggle to fill up. A 5-star den is a breeze with 4 competent players, but if you try to do it solo or with one other person, the NPCs are a complete gamble.

I had some fun playing it in the evening after I beat it, but eventually the fun tapered off. It's a shame, too, as this one should've been easy to complete the Dex for. Frustratingly, one of the Pokemon only spawns in a specific region with certain weather conditions. Could not get it to show up at all. Trading's a bit of a pain so sadly I fell off the game before I could round out the Dex,

I'll see if the upcoming DLC brings me back in. For the most part, this was enjoyable while it lasted but I don't find myself really wanting to replay it any time soon. I think that's pretty standard for Pokemon games anyway.

First thing, people have been hating on the fact that a fair amount of the national Pokedex being cut, but honestly, I didn't mind that at all. It meant that I could focus on experimenting with a team of almost all new Pokemon.

The game isn't a huge step up graphics wise from Sun & Moon, but it's fine overall.

The gyms are SO much fun. I love the concept, plus the battle music for them is absolutely one of my favorite tunes from Pokemon ever. When the crowd starts singing/chanting... Just... Holy Arceus.

The story is also a big improvement from Sun and Moon (wasn't a fan of Team Skull or the Aether Foundation).

Don't listen to most of the bad reviews. From what I see, in general, is that they're really just complaining about the Pokedex stuff, which is a small matter in a really solid entry in the Pokemon franchise.
titles: Awesome First Mainline Pokemon Switch Game

review_contents:
1) Its a very linear game, you go from gym to gym and then the champion and at the very end you battle some bad guys. Usually in the other games, you battle the enemy team or they cause some mischief and you have to deal with them first but thats not the case here and it was kind of disappointing

2) very babied down, with Hop talking to every minute and even while battling. They tell you what moves are supereffective and which are not (tho not if you do not have the pokedex entry). And the battles are too easy, why do I keep winning!?! The champion was too easy. I need a Cynthia okay

3) I love Pokemon Camp. My favorite thing to do is going to the camp and just watching my Pokemon interact and play with them. I want to make a 100 curries and its just so much fun.

4) I like that you get the exp share build in cuz that way I was able to switch my team around and not be stuck with the 5 i got in the beginning of the game and 1 HM slave speaking of which I love that there are no HMs in this game

5) the game is short took me 24 hours to reach the champion and I normally do not play post game but finding Pokemon to fill the pokedex is so much easier and fun than previous games that I am actually attempting to complete the dex. The surprise trade feature has helped a lot since I do not have the Shield version of the game. I do wish I could add a friend instead of just exchanging cards with them and never know any updates about them.

That is all I have to say, it is still a very enjoyable game, wish there was a hard mode but customizing your character, the wild area, pokemon camp, the league, the pokemon are very great. The story, direction and pacing however not so great.
titles: Been playing Pokemon for 10 years, here are my thoughs

review_contents:
Ever since I was little I have always been excited about when a new pokemon game would come out and what new features will be added. This game did not disappoint. It took me almost 10 hours to get the first four badges then the game speeds up and I beat it in about 16 hours. This is probably my 3rd or 4h favorite pokemon game after soul silver and sun.
People need to get over the fact that not all pokemon are in it and that you have to set up your team differently. The real fun of a pokemon game for me is always after you beat the game and catch all the pokemon and do what ever battle tower game they have. The story could have been a little longer but I‚Äôm sure for people that are unfamiliar with pokemon will have hours of fun trying to beat the game. I think the looks of the pokemon have come a long way and the graphics are the greatest they have ever been in a pokemon game.
My advice buy the game if you like pokemon. If you don‚Äôt or want a game with the full Pok√©dex buy yourself a ds and those games and pretend that this great game doesn‚Äôt exist.
titles: It‚Äôs not my favorite pokemon game but it is still great!

review_contents:
I loved this game, it hooked me in with its plot, it‚Äôs graphics, the Pok√©mon that was there, but I refuse to give it a 5 star rating because when it comes down to it, this is the weakest Pok√©mon game in the franchise, rivaling Sapphire/Ruby/Emerald.

When the plot tries to be interesting, it sort of nose-dives into the abyss and kind of stays there. Despite Champion Leon‚Äôs connection to the rival of this game, the characters aren‚Äôt fleshed out enough. I thought that the gym leaders would get involved in trying to save Galar from the evil that is released halfway through the game (referencing Black and White‚Äôs plot), but aside from being worried, they don‚Äôt get involved.

The post-game content here is by far the worst part of this game, Zamazenta and Zacian arrives to help the player against fighting a Dyramaxed monster and once the post-game comes around, the two legendary Pok√©mon that represents the hero of Galar are renegaded to capture fodder and that‚Äôs it, in this game‚Äôs case, Zacian comes, acts crazy because some sort of pathetic attempt of descendants or ancestors of the original legendary hero of Galar thought that they could control Zacian and/or Zamazenta? Talk about weak.

The Pok√©mon here are great for long time fans of the franchise, but the Galar exclusive roster of Pok√©mon is very, very weak.

The camping aspect of this game is interesting enough and prevented me from falling asleep multiple times during the post game.

I thought Team Yell would‚Äôve been the worse part of the game, but that honor goes to the ancestors of the legendary hero of Galar, alongside the post-game content.

The graphics and the concept of Dynamaxing was by far the best aspect of this game, the stadiums looks great and sort of 3D is interesting. Gloria and her male counterpart was interesting enough. They look like teenagers rather than your standard 10 year old male and female Pok√©mon protagonists and I think that‚Äôs what makes players not cringe while playing the game.

This game just feels like soppy seconds from Game Freak and Nintendo. It definitely isn‚Äôt worth the price that was placed here, $40 would‚Äôve been more than enough.
titles: It was great... until it wasn‚Äôt... *spoilers inserted to get points across*

review_contents: Honestly the most beautiful Pok√©mon game I have ever played. I was having tons of fun within the first few minutes, had a team full of Pok√©mon I‚Äôll have trouble choosing to replace within the first fifteen- no complaints so far! For new players or old, this is an awesome title that clearly had some serious work put into it compared to its predecessors! It has captured the same sense of wonder that I felt first playing Ruby at age 8. I can not recommend this game enough, test out your friend‚Äôs copy if you‚Äôre afraid to buy at this price with your worries, but I guarantee you won‚Äôt be disappointed.

I know there‚Äôs a lot of controversy around this game, but honestly it‚Äôs underserved, and I‚Äôm not going to get into it here.. I think this game‚Äôs best feature is the wild area and the events. If you‚Äôre not into online competitive, you typically will stop playing the game once you beat the league. But what I love about Sword/Shield is that the ever changing wild area and new Gigantamax Pok√©mon give you a reason to keep playing. I also actually enjoyed the challenge of filling all 400 slots of the Pokedex! And with the DLC coming, I think this game will hold up much better than previous installments. I also got my brother in law and his son into the game- and it‚Äôs their first ever Pok√©mon game- and they‚Äôve gotten the hang of it pretty well. Fun for all!
titles: It‚Äôs not a bad game you guys are just mean

review_contents:
I don't want to delve deeply into the controversy behind "Gamefreak being lazy" but I personally am not bothered by changes/cuts in content. It's Pokemon. You're probably still going to enjoy many aspects of the game. There's plenty of content in this game to enjoy and I understand that further developing it by including all 890 pokemon would've greatly delayed the release or possibly result in a cut of quality in some other aspect of the game.

Controls: 3.5/5
Moving in the overworld can be annoying probably because of how movement mechanics with the left joystick isn't refined. Maybe I just need for time and practice with it, but steering on the bike can be difficult especially in more narrow areas like in cities. One specific example I ran into was when I was trying to steer to enter a staircase however I over shot the turn. So I turned around but the bike's range of motion for a turn is too large to make a direct turn into the staircase. I was stubborn and tried multiple times to make the turn but ultimately just got off the bike and walked. Very minor annoyance.
Trying to climb ladders in the overworld has also been difficult at times. There have multiple times where I have had to fidget around the ladder area to find the right angle of approach to use it.

Game mechanics: 5/5
The core game mechanics were never designed to be overly complex. It's a turn based rpg which is refined and made interesting via strategy utilizing additional mechanics like type adv, EV/IVs, natures, etc. I think this is the greatest appeal of Pokemon games. At face value it is simple enough for young audiences or casual players. However if one wants to delve deeper into customizing their pokemon and teams there is a lot of depth and strategy.
Gigantamaxing looks ridiculous because it is but that is the appeal. I initially thought is was stupid but after experiencing it firsthand I enjoy it. It adds an interesting aspect to strategy in battles and the animations for it are very well done. Also seeing a giant, Godzilla-sized Pidove facing you asking for a fight is pretty great.
The raids mechanics is great. It covers a wide variety of entertaining game design points. It promotes another type of multiplayer experience outside of competitive battling. Completing them merits a wide variety of useful items and powerful Pokemon to catch. It provides variety to the standard wild battle mechanic.
The open world, "wild area" has been a great breath of fresh air. Pokemon has always been very linear in progression especially while still completing the storyline. In the preceding games, I have often felt tired of having to trek a linear path to get to the next gym, being confined to encounter the same group of pokemon in the routes leading to the gym. However, with the inclusion of the wild area, I have been able to take breaks from just following the paths of the routes and periodically go back to the wild area to level grind, catch pokemon, or just roam around looking for items or do raid battles. The linear route walking for gyms is still how storyline progression is conducted however it is refreshing to have the option of branching off to take a break from it. Additionally, the wild area has a wide variety of pokemon so you will never be bored of having to encounter the same exact set of pokemon every wild battle. You can easily just bike over to a different section of the wild area to find a new batch of pokemon. There is also a wide range of levels in the wild pokemon which is great for level grinding or to just catch a pokemon already at a high level to speed up preparing for a gym battle.

Graphics: 5/5
I wasn't expecting anything amazing. It's a pokemon game. The bulk of the game content I will be paying attention to is the battle scenes. The animations for the moves are well done and smooth. The only minor issue I've run into is when the camera angles change in battle there's an occasional stutter if I select an attack move just as the camera angle is changing. It doesn't negatively affect my experience of the game though.
The open world

Plot/Dailogue: 3/5
When I first started playing this game, I was worried that there would be an obscene amount of cut scenes and dialogue like in Sun and Moon. However, the pacing of when you get stopped to talk with NPCs for the main story is a lot better in this game and the text scroll speed and dialogue length isn't unbearable. That being said, the content of the conversation is very childish/elementary level and the personalities of a lot of characters are often cringe-y (which is honestly to be expected from a game that is marketed to also sell for young children). To this my solution is just skim read and gloss over the storyline. I personally am playing this game because I want to build a competitive team for online battling so the main story is just a means to an end so that I can get to the stage of the game where I can breed and EV train.
The main issue I have with Pokemon games lately is that it is in a sense a "rpg trying to hard to be an rpg while failing to be an rpg" (if that makes sense). There has been the addition of content to customize the appearance of your character by selecting skin tone/hairstyle/etc as well as selecting outfits. This is as far as customizing your character goes. Which I am fine with because the most important customization aspect of these games is your pokemon and how you build your team.
However, I get extremely annoyed at how the NPCs of the games are overly developed in their personalities, dialogue and mannerisms while you are just forced to stand there and only have the text response options of essentially "Yes" or "No (...which eventually leads to a blanketed "Yes" for the sake of progressing the story). I get especially irked by the rivals. It often feels like they are overly enigmatic, constantly excited and talkative to compensate for your character having no dialogue and being limited to one word responses.

Conclusion: It's pokemon. It will always make a great gift for anyone of any age. There is content in the game for anyone to like, especially with the added content and mechanics of this one. There are minor issues with the game however they do not ruin the overall experience that this version has to offer. I have been enjoying playing so far and am looking forward to building competitive teams to use online.
titles: It's Pokemon. Great, safe gift to give. You'll definitely find something you'll enjoy in it.

review_contents: I wanted to love this game, I really did. I had received the switch for xmas and bought Zelda soon after, and that game exceeded all of my expectations so that made my expectations for this game even higher. I loved the first and second gen pokemon games, they were a huge part of my childhood and I replay them every couple of years. I thought a game made nearly 20 years later would be more complex and have more intricacies. Overall the game was lacking, it's basically a straight line to the end of the game, you can't spend hours exploring like you can even on the simple maps of the original pokemon games. I beat this game in 3 days and even got a little bored doing so. There is no exploring under seas, and beating all of the gym leaders and the champion was no challenge at all. I know this is a game technically made for children, but so were the original games and those still hold a challenge for me. I hope any future pokemon games that are released can live up to the name.

Despite all the hearsay , and controversy, I found this game to be EXCELLENT. As a person who has played every generation of Pok√©mon game , I will say that the story felt shorter , and that it was different , more focused on creating a new experience than cashing in on our nostalgia . If you‚Äôre on the fence and unsure , I highly encourage you to dive in , the complaints aren‚Äôt well founded . Quality of life improvements have made this game a what it is , pc access anywhere , no more HMs , a fast travel system , easier to transfer egg moves , an IV checking item , nature changing mints , IV hyper training in the post game (makes ANY Pok√©mon viable stat wise) quicker breeding and 2 nurseries , a charm that increases shiny spawn rates and another for critical captures , and hours and hours of online vs and raids . No it isn‚Äôt as deep graphically as other games , but gamefreak isn‚Äôt a true AAA game company , they are small time accompanied by several other companies that market Pok√©mon through various media and merchandising . But it is still the best the franchise has ever looked , I felt engaged beginning to end . Camping and playing with your Pok√©mon was an excellent addition as well , I have spent hours playing with various mons , just to see how they move and play and interact with each other in camp.I love the new Pok√©mon themselves as well , they are a fairly balanced blend of the aesthetics that have changed between the years , some more humanoid or modern , some have that classic monster look , even just the 3 starters and their evolutions capture this beautifully . And last of all , the competitive is more fun , balanced , and easy to approach than ever . And the addition on the dynamax is just a more balanced combination of Z-moves and Mega-evolution , all Pok√©mon can do it , it lasts 3 turns , and it in no way will guarantee victory , but can provide a boost to your edge in battle , versus battles are more involved with field placement than ever , status ailments and weather teams are viable again .Just all in all a great experience .
titles: One of the best the franchise has ever made

review_contents:
There was a lot of negative backlash before the game came out because of the reduced Pokedex. At first I thought it wouldn't be an issue for me, I'm mostly casual about Pokemon games. However, when I couldn't carry my favourite Vivillon from Pokemon X across I was kinda bummed.

Could they have done more? Yes. It feels a bit unpolished... rushed. I feel as if every other Pokemon game I've played were longer experiences. The older games had better caves and routes hands down. Since the Nintendo DS versions, those previous games also had more Pokemon to play with. There are older games on the Switch that look better than this, but it doesn't look bad. Some human voice acting really wouldn't hurt, but overall the music is well done.

I don't care too much for Dynamax, this version's gimmick which makes Pokemon extremely large. You get really cool items for doing it, so I take part in them + the gyms have them. However, I'm not excited by it. <rant>To be honest, I don't know why they stopped doing Mega Evolutions, they could have made that life long instead of a gimmick.</rant>

The Wild Area is a special place that gives you a freedom to roam the Pokemon world in different habitats. Since I've been playing Breath of the Wild, it doesn't really feel open to me (maybe not their fault). It's still pretty nice. However, it never felt not critical. When I got tired of catching and wanted to advance the plot, I just stuck to the routes and the game didn't care one bit.

Unlike previous games, in this game you cannot catch Pokemon that are a higher level than you. That simple mechanic made the Wild Area less appealing for me. Masterminding how to take down a level 40 Pokemon with my party of 20s was pretty fun and I would have really liked to catch it.

The story is "meh" at best. Aside from Black/White, these games never made an attempt for a story. And that's fine, I think if they stuck with the sports theme without distractions this game would have been better off.

It sounds pretty negative, but otherwise it's a great experience. It's a standard Pokemon game, really great mechanics that hasn't gotten old as yet. They also made a lot of quality of life improvements with regards to moving around the world and moves which are definitely welcomed. I'm looking forward to the DLC as well. And generally, I'm still having a good time with it.

If you like Pokemon, pick this one up! If you're new to the main game series, this is the most usable one by far.
titles: Pretty fun! Go with an open mind

review_contents: As a fan of playing Pok√©mon on a Nintendo device for 2 decades, I‚Äôm very disappointed. The game has absolutely cheapened itself almost beyond all recognition, the graphics are incredibly disappointing given what we‚Äôve come to expect from Mario odyssey and Zelda breath of the wild, and the game play has gotten so easy you‚Äôre almost guaranteed to not ever fail. When I first played as a teen I was enthralled with the challenge and strategy. Now a 5 year old could play it. The game had vapid storyline and completely robs your player of any agency to play the game on your own. I agree with a lot of the other constructive negative reviews already posted. I waited in anticipation for the next great Pok√©mon adventure and I‚Äôm so sad at what was produced here. I desperately hope someone at Pok√©mon HQ takes over from the train wreck of this project and makes a triumphant return to a great history of great games.

Having played every Pokemon game except for the diamond/pearl genre, I can safely say this is the best, most complete entry in the franchise. Could they have done more? Sure. The 3D models bring enough life to the game that the "story" portion finally feels like a proper RPG. Speaking of which, the battles also have a lot more impact (especially the gym battles). Great usage of camera angles and amazing sound direction makes them more satisfying. If you've played Persona 4 Golden/Persona 5 you'll know what I'm talking about.

The ONE thing I absolutely dislike about the game is the difficulty though. It's not hard to just have an option in the settings to turn off all the assist stuff like showing which Pokemon an enemy is gonna switch to or what moves are/aren't effective. Some of us want to think.
titles: Don't let the naysayers disinterest you

review_contents:
This has been the only game to pull me out of my gaming funk. The mechanics are great and I actually enjoy the dynamaxing a lot, though it does feel a little rushed in that all moves of the same type in dynamax form are the same move.

I would love to see a hideout that's similar to the Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald in the next game, not that is necessary but the decorating is a fun extra aspect that could be there.

The new Pokemon are all really cool, there's a lot of unique and very inventive designs in this generation. I would love to have seen the full Pokedex in this one but I understand that would greatly increase the time it takes to make, I think I'd be happy to wait longer for a more fleshed out game in the future. Nonetheless, I absolutely adored it and highly recommend that you play it.

I liked the game. The reason I give it only three stars is because it wasn‚Äôt what I expected. I loved Pok√©mon games when I was a kid. I had red, gold and sapphire. It has been years since my gameboy days but, on a particularly nostalgic day, I decided I was going to give it a try. To my surprise, it was a lot different than I remembered. The graphics were great and the game was fun but I felt like the game itself was rushed. There were hardly any side quests or other activities to do in the game.
I remember the older games had mines you could dig in and Pok√©mon beauty contests you could enter. I also remember a secret base in one game which I spent a ton of time on. I enjoyed all of these extra activities and it made the game last longer. I wish the new game had more extra things like those for you to do. It just seemed like there wasn‚Äôt much else to do besides getting though the gym battles. I also was not a fan of the wild area. It felt like they were just trying to put all of the Pok√©mon you will find in the game in one place instead of giving you a larger game world to explore. Getting to travel to a lot of new areas and towns was one of my favorite things about the old games. The amount of area to explore seemed endless. This was not the case in Pok√©mon sword.
If this were the first Pok√©mon game I ever played, I wouldn‚Äôt have any complaints. Since I have played others in the past, I just felt this game was lacking. The game was still fun and entertaining but I was expecting more.
titles: Fun game but a bit disappointing if you played the older Pok√©mon games.

review_contents:
It‚Äôs a Pok√©mon game, I played the entire thing of course. But I‚Äôve also played every other generation of Pok√©mon game, and I can say after experiencing it to the fullest, it leaves a lot to be desired.

First of all the total time I spent just playing the story line is little to nothing compared to the other Pok√©mon games. The fact I beat the ‚Äúelite 4‚Äù version in this game on the first try definitely tells you these games have changed. I remember in my copy of emerald if I rushed through the game I would be stuck for several hours grinding the elite 4.

The catch rates of Pok√©mon have also been vastly increased, and Pokemon like the legendaries offered in this game are not nearly as special as they were. And don‚Äôt even get me started on dexit, as someone who spent hundreds of hours as a kid shiny farming Pok√©mon and can no longer transfer these Pok√©mon to the newest title it‚Äôs honestly a joke.

I would recommend skipping this generation as my biggest hope is that Nintendo redeems itself by remaking 4th gen with the full Pok√©dex.
titles: It‚Äôs not a Pok√©mon game if it‚Äôs just ‚Äúokay‚Äù

review_contents: I have been playing Pokemon games ever since GameBoy Color back when I was a kid. This is not on par with other games that are worth $60 like Breath of the Wild and Mario Odyssey. I am disappointed that I paid that much for this game. It is a great Pokemon game but they could have done so much more. It is at most worth as much as the rest of the 3DS Pokemon games at $40. The graphics are barely better than 3DS, no voice acting, the animations are extremely lazy, some cut scenes aren't even scenes at all, just low res pictures. I am disappointed when a company rushes an unfinished game to market and it sells for $60. I will not be buying the next Pokemon game as a pre-order.

Pros:
- Great Graphics
- New Pokemon
- New Abilities and Items

Cons:
- Does not have full pokedex
- Linear game play

Pokemon Sword and Shield is a great start to next gen consoles. It has upgraded graphics and animations. I play competitive online battles and the game introduced new items which make it easier for training Pokemon for competitive play much easier. It is a great game for new players, however veterans players will find it lack of content. After beating the game in about 25+ hrs, there is very little post game and about 60% of the pokedex was cut out from the game which sucks. Overall the game is okay, its a great start for next gen but the game has potential to be even better.
titles: Mediocre game but has potential to be Great

review_contents:
It is Pokemon, but probably the dumbest of the entire series. Way too easy, and I don't necessarily feel any of the titles in the series are hard. You will be reminded about 200 times that Leon is the undefeated champion. And that you learned type matches. Also, 90% of your favorite Pokemon didn't make the cut. Dynamax is absolutely stupid, and mega-evolution is gone in favor of it.

But it is Pokemon. And in 3D. Wild area is cool and there are things to catch. Of all the titles in the series, this is the worst. 2 stars because at least they kept my Eevee.

(WARNING: Some things may change in the future of the game!). The game was very fun to play through. The new Pokemon were pretty good, but they did not add the national Pokedex and didn't add all the other pokemon from previous gens (only 400 Pokemon in the game). The battle system is pretty easy and you can breeze through the game if you know what you're doing. The graphics are beautiful and you can customize your character. It's easy to get money so you have a lot of chances to buy clothes. Overall, I recommend this game to people who don't really care about the difficulty of the game and just want to enjoy playing it. I recommend that you buy this game when it is on sale due to the game not feeling like a full experience of a Pokemon game.
titles: Does Not Contain All Pokemon From Previous Generations!

review_contents:
Don‚Äôt listen to all the hate these games are getting. I‚Äôve played every mainline Pokemon game going back to Red and Blue and the people saying this is the worst game must have played a far different game then I did.

Is it perfect? No, but none of the previous games really were. The Exp share is back with a vengeance and it makes everything a cakewalk for experienced players, but they‚Äôve had this feature since X and Y so not really a surprise. Some of the new Pokemon designs are lazy, Weezing with a top hat? Really? Yet there are also really unique and charming ones that they added that shouldn‚Äôt be discredited.

With that being said, I played through the entirety of both Sword and Shield and I had a really great time with it. The characters are extremely charming and have actual arcs and personality that I always felt the other games lacked. You can go camping with Pokemon which is pretty much a Pokemon version of Nintendogs which I very quickly became enamored with. And the gym battles actually feel fresh and exciting again, in a way I don‚Äôt think they have since I first played Blue as a kid. And despite what people are saying, there is a very large selection of Pokemon you can collect. I‚Äôve been trying to complete the dex for several days now and there‚Äôs still ones I‚Äôm trying to find, which I think says something.

So is it the best Pokemon game? Probably not. But I had a lot of fun with it and I think it‚Äôs well worth the price tag.
titles: Worth the price, don‚Äôt listen to all the hate

review_contents: As an adult who still loves this franchise, I found this game to be fun and even challenging at some points. Sure I beat every battle without losing, but that doesn't mean it was too easy. I love the variety of pokemon even though they left out some of my old favorites. They made up for it with a fresh batch of super cute little mons! It took about 30 hours to beat the game, which is usual for me. There is some after game stuff too, and dynamaxing pokemon isn't the worst gimmick they've thought of. Overall, I had fun playing and loved the travel features so you don't have to teach pokemon useless moves anymore to swim on water or fly to another town. Super fun to play on the TV or on the go! Great for kids and for the grown up kids who have always played these games. Thanks Nintendo! I thought the graphics were great in spite of what some fans were expecting. I'm sure an ultra realistic game will come to us eventually, but this game is based on anime style after all, and it holds true to that.

Hola buenas noches, se hizo la compra del juego de pokemon espada el dia 4 de noviembre en preventa, ya que el estreno del juego era el dia 15 de noviembre.
el problema que tengo es que no puedo descargar el juego en la consola nintendo switch, ya que me aparece en la consola que el codigo no esta disponible.

solicito amablemente una respuesta ya que no he podido descargar el juego y no lo he podido disfrutar o me hacen la devolucion del dinero

gracias,

This game looks pretty and cool despite the National Dex cut (which isn‚Äôt really all that bad at first glance to a casual audience) I would recommend it to those who just want to start on a fresh slate of new Pokemon and the new fans can go back to the older games to have a fun experience
titles: Is Sword and Shield Worth it Despite Nat Dex Cut

review_contents:
Honestly I‚Äôm disappointed with this game. I‚Äôve been an avid Pok√©mon fan since I was playing the original Pok√©mon Sapphire on the game boy, and I‚Äôve loved every single generation up until now. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, the graphics are great (at times), the overworld is so fun to explore, and I loved the game for every second I played it. However, the one reason I don‚Äôt think this game was that great, was because it‚Äôs on the switch, yet it doesn‚Äôt truly seem to reflect that very concept. It‚Äôs capabilities as a game can be far more expansive, higher quality, and more, just like the other switch games: Breath of the Wild, the Witcher 3, and Skyrim. The storyline was also dull, and the postgame was depressing. I love Pok√©mon, but this just doesn‚Äôt seem to feel like what I‚Äôve grown up playing with.

One thing I think that really caused me to lose interest was the concept of legendaries. They used to be so much more enticing and mysterious, but now they just hold such a trivial feel to them. Legendaries are legendary for a reason, so make them feel that way.
titles: Good because I enjoy Pok√©mon, bad because of everything else.

review_contents:
I‚Äôve played every Pok√©mon game since red and blue. This is garbage. The story is crap, the characters are obnoxious and forgettable, the features in this version are weak and unimpressive and there is no endgame aside from the battle tower. The map seems very small and restrictive.

This may be the last Pok√©mon game I‚Äôll ever buy.

The first pokemon game I played was Pokemon Let's go Pikachu, so I'm standing from a point of normal video game player. I did finish the entire Pokemon Let's go game and spend lots of time grinding. Kinda tedious but I pulled it through. For Pokemon Sword& shield, after I got three gym badgers, I couldn't motivate myself to continue to play. I think the name of this game should be called Lets go Pokemon Delux. Because the only difference is in the story and a big open park to capture giant pokemon. I understand that's pretty much how every generation of the pokemon game works. There is never much change in gameplay style throughout each generation. But after Pokemon lets go, I just don't want to spend so much time on doing the same things in Pokemon sword anymore. When I started the game and try to decide which starter pokemon to pick, I found the final evolution of the three starter pokemon are so damn ugly. So I was already very disappointed at 5 min into the game. So unless you are a hard cord pokemon fan, I don't recommend you to buy this game, especially if you have already played Let's go pokemon.

Funny how I got Sword for my girlfriend for Christmas and she got me Shield. I haven't played a Pokemon game since Ultra Moon and that version didn't excite me too much. For a new generation I must say I was impressed. I felt vibes from both classic Pokemon games to brand new features. Even though there was the rant about "no National Dex," the amount of Pokemon to choose from was hard cause there were still so many types. The region was stunning as well and the British theme was done well. Can't wait to see what other Pokemon games will potentially be on the Switch.
titles: A great Beginning for Pokemon on Switch!

review_contents:
It's Pokemon, but with arbitrary rules that make it pointless to try and catch anything. Instead of all the previous games where you could catch anything you could catch and just can't control them without bages, you just can't catch them for no explainable reason. Some people play to beat the game, and some play to catch all they can, but you can't do the second.
The game is also absurdly easy, just do some raids, get xp candy and have a level 90 Pokemon that can blast through everything with no effort, just push A to continue. The whole idea of working the system to take advantage of strengths and weaknesses is pointless because you can just kill everything, the game has no reason to play, it has no challenge and you can't catch everything.
titles: No reason to play the game. No challenge and limited catching.

review_contents:
It was mediocre. Pokemon Sun/Moon was marginally better, but basically the series hasn't evolved (pun intended?) past the core original design. They try "new" things that don't really add to the strategy. Even more so, this entry cuts down on the story outside of gym battles where each event that occurs is accompanied by the "adults" telling you children to just focus on the gym challenge while they go investigate the big explosion.

Only in the post-game mission(s) do you get to experience more of that and actually help out with situations. It was disappointing, but it wasn't bad.
titles: Another mediocre entry in an ongoing series that needs to evolve.

review_contents: Pok√©mon Sword on the Switch captures everything that your remember from the classic games while adding fun new features to make it a new, unique game. The new ability to see wild Pok√©mon is helpful for those quick sessions that you don‚Äôt want to spend battling. The wild area is fun and full of great Pok√©mon to help level up your team. The story is fun, albeit short. The graphics are a great new take on the Pok√©mon series and once you‚Äôre used to them, you won‚Äôt miss the old graphics other than for nostalgia purposes. Highly recommend this game for those who played the classics and have an open mind!
titles: Great addition to the legendary series

review_contents:
It‚Äôs a great game. The online features are a train wreck and need to be updated/fixed but the core game is very fun and has several quality of life improvements that make it way better than any of the previous titles. Post-game content is very lacking and the max raid feature is a mixed bag without Internet, especially later in the game when they get too difficult to complete alone without very specific preparation.

The game has many small issues like wonky features and an embarrassing amount of reused character models but it‚Äôs still a good game that‚Äôs worth the price.
titles: 160 hours of gameplay and 315 Pok√©mon caught, I got my money‚Äôs worth!

review_contents:
I love this game! I'm 28yrs and I've played through every generation of Pok√©mon's main series games. This is a top 5 game in the Pok√©mon catalog. I believe that with the upcoming DLC that this game (and its counterpart Pok√©mon Shield) will take the franchise further beyond the typical once beaten-no replay value games of the past. I have already pre-ordered the expansion pack to be honest.

I was very upset when I first heard the new that all of the Pok√©mon weren't going to be available for Sw&Sh but I'm hoping that there will be more DLC after the two slotted for release later this that will add some more of the older Pok√©mon into the coding. I really don't know what else people expect from GF/The Pok√©mon Company. We know that there would never be very drastic changes to the series.

The 4 stars are in regards to the product, not Amazon.

The Pokemon Sword/Shield games are a great play for any Pokemon fan, but they also have their cons. The game only has 400 Pokemon you can currently catch/store *this has been slightly expanded upon since the release date*, and any future Pokemon will become available through the download of DLC content, both being the Isle of Armor and the Crown Tundra expansions ($30 each, are you serious?). The story may also seem relatively short if you're a veteran Pokemon fan, I got about 25-30 hours in before completing.
titles: Huge pokemon fan, not a huge Gamefreak fan

review_contents: After over 3 hours of gameplay I am still enjoying it a lot. The graphics are definitely the best out of all the Pok√©mon games. The map may seem small at first but there is actually a lot to do in the areas that will have you occupied for hours. The character customization is part that I am finding really cool. You have the ability to change the hair, hair color, clothing, shoes and accessories. The game is also very user friendly and easy to navigate. The downside is that you cannot just go out and level up your Pok√©mon and catch whatever level without defeating gym leaders. Another downside is that the cut scenes don‚Äôt have voice overs which would of been great add. Other than that great game.

I think this is a good game, even with the backlash around it, it is a bummer that not all the pokemon is gonna be in the game but overall, it is a good game, especially with the music and the character customizations, those are really good parts of this game, also with the battle animations and the battle mechanics, the graphics could do better but again overall, good game.

They clearly didnt do any effort on this story and just half baked it. Also to add the game play is boring, the routes are too short, the towns are too small and boring, literally nothin to talk to in the people in the cities, battle moves animation is horrid and the main story is trash.

All they sorta did was a add some good environment graphics and the dynamax music in the gym was cool. I guess the wild area was pretty decent.

4/10

Maybe another studio will pick this up and hope the next one is better.
titles: Dissapointing game from this great series

review_contents: Underwhelming effort from Game Freak. This game would be fun if I was six years old. Sad since the Switch is the home of series bests (Breath of the Wild, Fire Emblem Three Houses, Mario etc.)

An enjoyable game, but not worth 60 dollars. I suggest you wait till the price drops unless you really love pokemon. Also, my package was delivered LATER than the date told. So, overall, it was the worst experience I could get for this game. It still was fun to play from time to time.
titles: Enjoyable, but not for 60 dollars (LATE DELIVERY)

review_contents: I found this game to be quite a bit better than the sun and moon series. The game play loop of pokemon is tried and true, but it gets a much needed change with the wild zone. The dexit makes me a little sad, but i wasn't going to port all 700 some monsters to one game anyway. The new pokemon feel more inspired than the last 2 generations. The old gen pokemon that made it is varied and mostly great. The coding and visuals could have been better and if you do too many early raids you will walk all over the competition.

Catch rates are completely messed up. Even being 10+ levels above a pokemon does not help in catching them. There are also lots of move balance issues. I am very upset with this purchase and my wife thinks we made a big mistake in spending money on these two games. Really sad to see such a good franchise do this.
hate this game so much it made me sell my switch, f off game freak

Coming from Sun and Moon, this game does so much better! The pacing, plot, characters, and Pokemon are all amazing! The Wild Lands adds a free roaming aspect that fits quite well for a Pokemon game. My only nitpick is that the game felt too short! I'm looking forward to the expansion to Sword and Shield!
titles: One of the best Pokemon games by far!

review_contents: The code was instantly delivered. The game itself I‚Äôm not gonna lie, I am disappointed they don‚Äôt have every Pok√©mon from the Pok√©mon universe. But they still have a good amount. around 400 Pok√©mon to catch. It‚Äôs been addicting filling out my Pok√©dex, my only other gripe with the game is that it‚Äôs too easy and they baby you. It‚Äôs almost impossible to lose a fight. I understand the demographic for this game is kids. But it‚Äôs not toddlers. There shouldn‚Äôt be any reason the game holds your hand that much. But besides those two issues the game is still a good Pok√©mon game.
Another excellent Pokemon game, if you liked previous games you will like this one. Don‚Äôt listen to the crybaby review bombs of the internet trolls who didn‚Äôt even by or play the game.
titles: If you like Pokemon you will

review_contents:
Personal Opinions First: (blowing off some steam)
Admittedly, I was one of the naysayers saying that the game is pretty lackluster, but I'd be a liar to say that without experiencing the game. So far, it is just FINE the way it is for now. Granted the whole #NationalDex movement on social media, I could care less about catching "all the freaking Pokemon" as Gotta Catch 'Em All back in the 90s. You seriously think most people would be able to keep transferring their old pokemon from the really early 2000s and still expect to be competitive at this time... Get over it, the times have changed. Do you really think that newcomers these days (young and old) want to try to compete on finishing a neverending Pokedex in which they need all the past games to play catch up? Stop that mentality. I'm approaching my mid 20's and I rarely have the OCD need to fill however many pokemon existing here. Games are for all ages yo. What appears good to a kid might not necessarily appeal to us veterans who have played since the Red/Blue days...

Objectively Speaking: **The MOST IMPORTANT PART OF THE REVIEW**
The Wild Area and all the little QoL features have me hooked, and it's much more fun playing with friends/other people interested in the game. There's no absolute need to sway people from one side of the argument to the other, vice versa. Surround yourself with whomever you think has the strongest opinion and let that guide you to make this purchase or not. Graphic details are all right given that this is Pokemon... if the game became like super fine detailed, I'd swear it might go on something like the PS4 or so. Or even, it might not be the Pokemon game I've known (stopped after Gen 3, picked back up after Gen 6 with X/Y) over these years. People are just blowing this whole debate to no end, and it's childish to even keep this rant going (given that a good chunk of the audience might be adult-age by now).

I'm sure the developers by now, have heard all of your voices; just give it a rest and let the rest of us who opted to buy the game - enjoy it.

Peace out guys.
titles: People who give bad reviews blindly are themselves B A D

review_contents: I was excited to play my first full pokemon game after playing red and blue on my old gameboy as a kid. I didn't own a 3ds so hadn't played a pokemon game since then. Purchased this mainly out of nostalgia and to finally get a chance to play on a big screen. The game kept me mildly entertained through the 30 hour playthrough, but it was very easy, linear, and there seemed to be less discovery and puzzles than I remember from some of the earlier games. This could also be the result of my tastes changing, but overall I wasn't terribly impressed. Was not surprised to see that they are releasing DLC already that expands the world. This feels like a portion of a game, with the full scope to be revealed through multiple future DLC...unfortunate.

This is a series seriously suffering from fatigue due to lack of innovation. There is definitely charm in between, but as a game it remains archaic. If you are a series veteran you will come across nothing truly new, and if you are a newcomer you may come across a game so easy you breeze through it. Perhaps that was the intention, to make it so you could let even an infant play it and succeed, and that is fine...or would be if that description did not fit the previous entry "Let's Go", a game after which they promised the next one would be better developed, challenging and for veterans.
Most people that follow this franchise will know wether they want this installment already, regardless of reviews. For parents looking for a gift I recommend the previous entry instead as it's more complete for the price, either version depending on their taste is better.

I would honestly say this is the best pokemon game since some of the earlier entries. The wild area is a blast and keeps the game interesting.

Specifically, you can tell they added a lot of content to the wild area, but the routes themselves throughout the game are a bit shorter than previous entries. This speeds the story up if that's something you're interested in, but if you enjoy and spend time in the wild area then the game will take quite a bit of time. Very happy.

I docked a star because I preordered this game through amazon for the $10 promotion credit. About 3 weeks later and I still have not received the promotional credit. The game is great but amazon has not fulfilled the preorder bonus yet.
titles: 5 Star game -1 Star for not Receiving Promo Code

review_contents: honestly i love the game, i preordered both sword and shield. theres so much more that could have been done with this game, but if its a sign of things to come. the gameplay is a good hybrid of classic pokemon plus a further expansion of the quality of life improvements of lets go. i dont care so much about the missing pokemon most of the cut ones were kind of lackluster or all ready covered. do we really need the regional birds, rats and pika clones of every generation or all the legendaries and mythics? yeah it sucks but what really bugs me the most is i preordered the game when amazon was offering a 10 dollar gift card after preordering. so i got both. stiiiil waiting on them gift cards

Nintendo Pokemon game. Pretty straight forward. This is the first one you can play on the TV with the Nintendo Switch which was SO exciting for me. This is the newest generation of Pokemon introducing new Galar regional versions of some older Pokemon as well as completely new Pokemon. The main thing with the Sword and Shield games is Dynamaxing Pokemon which allows you to make one of your Pokemon HUGE for a few turns. Also the first game to introduce a wild area of this scale and style. It really is the best.
titles: Favorite in the series thus far

review_contents: I pre-ordered this game for my son a few months back and it arrived on the morning of November 15th. It was originally scheduled to be released in December but the date was moved back. So far my son has been playing the game non-stop and says he really likes it. Apparently there are hundreds of Pok√©mon you can catch and should keep him entertained for a few weeks. It did come with a free download for pre-orders that I asked him if he got and he said yes.
Item received without game in case.

The game overall is meh. Not to mention the lack of mons, GTS, pokebank (Home not yet up), there are other issues. The overall story is okay, but your rival has the exact same movements as the one in SM, just a different skin. The graphics are not up to par for the Switch, especially when shaking trees for berries - it's quite sad. Lack of end game material. The game is okay, but definitely not worth the price tag.

The overworld mons and wild area are pretty neat, and some of the new mons are pretty cool as well.

I thought everyone was exaggerating when they said this was bad. I'm not a hardcore fans and I havent played all the older games but I have a good sense of the Pokemon world and various regions and such. Everything is mediocre. Gameplay, music, animations, graphics, available pokemon and story are all ok at best. The only thing that is fun about this game is Raid battles. Don't waste your money on this. It is no way worth $60, maybe $30 at most.

I have played every installation with my wife over the past 8 years and this one a solid "meh." We usually buy one of each version to play but we did not for sword and shield. The game play is quick and light but I did like the walking pokemon features in the wild zones. If you have played most games in the series, it is worth a play. For first time players, pick a different version with a better story and wait for the next game on switch.
titles: Not great, not bad. A solid middle ground

review_contents: Do not buy this game! It's the worst ever main series Pokemon game. It's just a waste of money. There are only 400 pokemons in this game and the main story is extremely short and boring. The graphics of this game is also terrible. In short, this game is just a shame of main series Pokemon games.

Ignore the hate and the negative reviews. This game is fantastic. Even after the end game, there's still so much to do. I haven't played a Pokemon game that could hold my attention like this since Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald. Those were my last favorite pokemon games.
titles: If you love Pokemon, get this game.

review_contents: Great game despite the initial bugs. They will have an update in the next couple days. Anazon delivered this very quickly as well.

Not much to say. It's a typical Pokemon RPG with same basic gameplay as all the past ones. There are a few differences in this and past games, just like every new game they release. It is a bit of a bummer that the entire Pokedex didn't make it in, but for me that was not a deal breaker.

I LOVE LOVE LOVE the max raids, and have spent more hours than I care to admit just doing max raid dens.

Pok√©mon Sword and Shield continues the trend of modern Pok√©mon being good but not great. A trend which can be very frustrating when you know its possible for the series to be so much better than it currently is. The game makes a lot of good changes that makes the overall Pok√©mon journey less tedious and more fun. It also successfully combines elements from the mainline Pok√©mon games, Pok√©mon Go and Lets Go. However, when compared to other Japanese RPGS it makes you realize how much the games are still lacking. The lacking graphics feel really outdated on the Switch. Also dated is the lack of voice acting during cutscenes. The game, even with the Wild Area, is extremely linear. While these type of issues may not bother others it does for me. Again, the game is not bad and I actually enjoyed it overall. But, it was consistently obvious the game could have been so much more.

if you like pokemon it is fun it has a few flaws but other wise is the funnest game it occasionally crashes but all games do at some point on nintendo switch the game is beautiful very fun even into post game sadly post game is breeding battle tower and tournaments but is fun and it has a side story for extra legendary it has a secret quest in water town after beating champion for a lucky egg it is in cafe

The first pokemon game made for children and ONLY for children. It checks the boxes to be functional without taking any extra step to make it better than ‚ÄúOK.‚Äù

Story: bad. Handholding, constant, annoying and flat characters. The past few games pokemon has solved the challenge of pacing by keeping the player on rails the entire game, and this is the worst and most obvious iteration of that.

Gameplay: it‚Äôs a pokemon game. It feels like pokemon, it plays like pokemon. Almost no postgame, almost no side content. Wild area is a nice concept but is barren and feels more like a segmented off gimmick. Don‚Äôt be mistaken into thinking that it‚Äôs integrated at all into the rest of the game.

Visuals: 3DS. The blockbuster switch games look like a big screen game you can play on the go. This game looks like a portable game you can put on a big screen. At the same time, these are some of the best new Pok√©mon designs in a long time despite the lack of polish and personality in everything else.

Not much to like or hate about it. If you enjoy Pok√©mon, it‚Äôs just another game in the series. The wild area is pretty neat, but I finished the game in a few days. There‚Äôs not a whole lot to do. I feel like I spent $60 on an Indy game over a full fledged title. Could use more time to really shine.

But to reiterate, if you‚Äôve been enjoying the games so far, there‚Äôs plenty to like about this one.

I really like the story of this game, and the new regional evolutions. The only negative thing I would say about this is the lack of things to do after you‚Äôve beaten the game. There is a little 3 hour thing to do at the end, but beside that, all you have is the battle tower and max raid battles. I hope they add an extra post game city or something because it can get really boring sometimes.

I would give it 5 stars but since the game doesn't include the national dex, I took one off. Aside from that, this game is a 100% improvement on what I think are the worst Pokemon games ever: Sun&Moon. Not sure what to write that hasn't been written already about this game in the reviews. I was one of those people initially who refused to play it and was looking for a reason to hate it, but after giving it an honest try, Iove it.
titles: I was wrong, this game is awesome

review_contents: This is what we all dreamed of playing when pokemon red and blue came out. It's very cool seeing all types of wild pokemon running around. Don't let the angry pro pokemon fan boys/girls detract you from buying this game. Its not perfect, maybe could have had some more features but overall I had a blast playing it and I know all pokemon fans will too.

This was a fun game. Works with the standard pokemon battle format of turn based battles. One new additional feature is that all your pokemon in your 6 slots earn experience, even if they did not battle an opposing pokemon directly. Great way to level up faster and less grinding. But overall it is not much different than past pokemon games. I got great game play and time spent to relive pokemon from my childhood. I hadn't played pokemon since the original Pokemon Red/Blue version.
