pokemon camp: have pokemon play with toys or make curry recipes. Curry has cool effects like take out status effects or heal pokemon. Similar to Pok√©mon-Amie and Pok√©mon Refresh, and Partner Play, but toned down.

Pok√© Jobs" Pok√©mon can complete requests, such as assisting in construction or cooking, to gain experience or rare item

Version differences: Main story is the same, but gym leaders (2 exclusives each version) and pokemon (21 exclusive each version) are different.

Graphics best in the series, but expected more seeing on that it's on a home console

Overall, enjoyable like past Pokemon main line series games. You don't get all the pokemon of past generations, but it's still a fun time
titles: Fun time, but not everyone is here

review_contents:
Sword and Shield are pretty much just a way for the company to cash in on their first mainline switch title before releasing the finished versions later on down the road. There are a lot of interesting ideas like camping, cooking, and the wild area that have potential but are not quite there yet due to what feels like features that were cut or just straight up missing. I wont talk about the cut pokemon because everyone has already done that.

Raid battles are fun but be warned if you do not have the online pass for the switch, the in-game trainers for the raid battles are W O R T H L E S S. The npcs will either bring unevolved pokemon or just stuff that will get crushed by the raid pokemon. Nothing hurts more than fighting a 5 star G-Max snorlax and one of your allies is rocking a magicarp.

The game story is... VERY unfinished to say the least. You spend 90% of your time battling through the gyms to become the champion which is pretty fun but then near the end of that you are suddenly thrown this half-baked scenario where you have to stop an evil pokemon A from destroying the world with little to no backstory on ANYTHING beforehand outside of the occasional "sword and shield hero stopped the darkest day".

There seems to be quite a bit to do at the endgame, if you want a good Ditto after you beat the game story go to the nursery in the wild area and then straight north of it along that same wall there is a raid den, use wishing stars on it till you see a purple light and you have a ditto. The star rating will tell you how many perfect IVs it will have. You can EV train your mons by sending them to a 24 hour seminar for the stat you want WITH the corresponding power band. May want to use vitamins instead if you want more specific levels in multiple stats. If you have the g-max meowth get it to 100, give it the amulet coin or luck incense and enter the champion cup with it in the lead of your party. G-max it every battle and just use g-max gold rush. You will pick up 99,999 coins every win and 24,000 something from the trainer themselves.

Anyways overall not a bad game but definitely not a finished game, the next versions of sword and shield will hopefully include what feels like is missing and have a more rounded and solid story to go with it. I got this game for $4 at gamestop using store credit, so for that price its worth. At $60 tho you may want to wait till it comes down a bit.

I want to start by saying that his game is fun and i'm enjoying playing it, but it is WAY to easy. I mean, mind numbly easy. Seriously, I can't stress how easy it is. There are lags, but only in the wild areas. Also, very annoying is trying to join other raid battles. Every time i get a pop up to join one, it's always to late. Late as in, it'll finally show on my feed to join and i'll click to join, but the battle is already over! But nothing is still worst then how freakin easy it is. It's the reason why I'm losing interest in playing. There's no challenge. Yes, there's raid battles, but that gets boring after the 10-20th time. One of the problem to why it's so easy is the wild area. It has so many strong pokemon, that gaining level is way to easy and fast. You can go from lvl 10 to lvl 45 within 30mins - 1hr. The main problem is how under level everyone is, especially the gym leaders. How has GameFreak not yet implemented lvl scaling or just a HARD mode? If, you even slightly train your pokemon, they are going to be over lvl. Anyways, enjoyable game, but way to easy.
titles: There's problems, but mine is how EASY it is

review_contents: This game is fantastic. The world feels more alive than any other Pokemon game, with other trainers and other Pokemon swarming all around in the Wild Areas. The new generation of pokes are really well made and well balanced, and there is always something to do or see. There's a tiny group of people on reddit who are trying to review bomb this game because they think they understand how 3D models work- but hilariously very few of these people have even played the game. I've been playing Pokemon since I was 6 years old, starting with Red, and this game far exceeded my expectations. The sales numbers are a testament to how good it is. I hated Let's Go Pikachu/Eevee, but this game totally redeems the series for me. Buy this game!
titles: Easily the best Pokemon game ever made, ignore the idiots trying to review-bomb

review_contents:
I rarely post reviews but this one needed to be said.

I‚Äôm a 30 yr. old male Pok√© fan who has enjoyed the franchise since the beginning. For years I‚Äôve dreamt of a full-scale, open world, triple A, big screen, big budget, surrounded sound, ass on the couch, Pokemon experience. For Sword and Shield, I purposely chose to ignore all the press as I wanted to go in blind and enjoy a pure, unbiased experience. I‚Äôve been waiting for the first 3D fully-realized main series game forever, so I pre-ordered from GameStop and asked my wife to pick it up on the day of release. In the words of Jack Slater: big mistake.

Most reviewers are being nice by saying: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a bad game, it just could‚Äôve been a little better.‚Äù The truth is, this is a BAD game and it could've been way better. It offends in the worst way a game could, by being boring. My recommendation is to not purchase or play this game. If you must play it, please wait for the price to drop. There should be cheaper used copies online soon, so keep an eye out. Please don't pay $60 - even if it's for your kids. It's simply not worth it. As another reviewer so accurately stated, buying this game perpetuates corporate greed and low standards for multi-million dollar gaming franchises.

This game is a lazy outing for the developer. For me, Sword and Shield had potential to be the best Pokemon game of all time. Like no one ever was. The unfortunate reality is, it represents the first watered-down, lazy, copy paste, main-line entry in the Pok√©mon series. This game is agonizingly easy; anyone with an ounce of Pok√© experience under their belt will be woefully over-prepared. Any trainer who houses an ounce of intelligence inside their skull or takes small pleasure in their sense of efficiency will find their brain continually moving into a sleepy state because there is literally no challenge. Most Pokemon games are a normal, balanced difficulty. In my opinion, S/M (I've heard X/Y too) started to bring the franchise down to easy mode, but this game brings us right down to beginner mode. As many have said, it‚Äôs literally ‚ÄúBaby‚Äôs First Pokemon‚Äù.

The hand-holding is so abundant, so aggressive that as a seasoned trainer I felt mentally insulted and exploratorily oppressed. Any sense of excitement and exploration is gone as the game forcibly babies you along every painful step of the way. They told me to go to town to find the train station. Hop waited on the trail for me to remind me. When I reached town, the game took over and showed a cut scene literally panning in on the train station. It's simply too much, were they targeting a 4-year old audience? Do they realize that a masive fan base exists amounts all age groups? I mean, I'm not looking for Grand Theft Pokemon but please give me at least the Pixar treatment. Let me have a little adult fun! The dialogue is so basic and unrealistic. It‚Äôs OK to have cut scenes but this game has long moments of characters just standing around, talking about nonsense, and saying nothing interesting. No change of view, creative angle, etc. Just same camera view, sitting there, ready to go to sleep.

Back to basics can be a legit strategy but it only works if everything you do actually put in the game is of utmost quality and depth. GameFreak pulled a crap sauce combo where they dumbed down the entire game even more so and the elements we love that they did leave intact, are for the most part, poorly done. This game takes accessibility to a disgusting level and partially destroys the essence of the game itself by doing so.

I hate writing this review, but I feel so ripped off. I can‚Äôt believe I paid full price for this game. Never again will I reserve a game or go in blind and trust that the developer will get it right. Pokemon is so popular and high selling, these developers could literally work with unlimited budget. Imagine what this game could have been if it were given an extra two years, more money, technology, and talent. There are developers with a micro fraction of the amount of resources that Nintendo/Pokemon/GameFreak has who put out vastly better games. This is simply inexcusable. I cannot help but feel like this entry was a slimy cash grab and they are laughing all the way to the bank. You've been warned :)
titles: Buying this game perpetuates corporate greed. Truly a lazy outing for the developer.

review_contents:
EDIT: I added a star cause after 20 hours I'm still enjoying this game, and cause after the first major town the tuning seems to improve for battling. I do a fair amount of random encounters, fight all trainers in new areas, and even with the mandatory EXP share I am a couple levels lower than the trainers I come up against. You can't do a lot of grinding, but that's not how I like to play Pokemon anyway.

I watched 3 reviews before buying this game. I loved X and Y, hated Sun and Moon, and I need to get my two cents in. This is not the perfect epitome of pokemon we've all been dreaming of since pokemon Stadium on N64. It IS a very enjoyable fresh adventure with good immersion and IMO great new pokemon designs. Dynamax I could care less and have no opinion on. I prefer classic battle styles.

Pros:
+Pokemon out in the world. Gyarados chilling in the lake. Great world immersion.
+Wow they nailed the gym challenge. It really feels like a football-level spectator sport.
+Character and pokemon designs are great. I actually want to catch em all, and evolve them to see what they become.
+The style and color palette for the world are great. It's a pretty game along the lines of Breath of the Wild.

Cons:
-What is with some of the textures in this game? It's like at the last minute Gamefreak realized it's not optimized, so they cut a load of corners. Some of the textures are grainy, as though they've been stretched wrong. N64 level graphics. It's pretty few and far between, but really. They know better.
-Draw distance is pretty short (see: optimization). Doesn't bother me, but it may bother you.
-They cut a bunch of the pokedex probably for optimization reasons. I own Nintendo's online pokebox cloud, I have all my faves stored. I don't really see the issue here. Is it disappointing? Yes. Does it ruin the game? I really don't think so. If all I do all the time is play my faves, I may as well go back to X and Y.
-EXP SHARE IS MANDATORY. Game loses a whole star for this. What the heck. As if pokemon isn't easy enough already. Do any battles or camping or anything, and your team will be over leveled in the next town. My workaround for this is just to keep swapping out my team with lower level pokemon, and that's actually been really enjoyable. But I shouldn't be forced to play like this for some kind of challenge.

All in all, I still love this game. It's simple, mostly beautiful, and how much you like it will really depend on how all the cons weigh with your play style. I would price it worth $40 new, not $60. I am looking extremely forward to the next installment where hopefully Gamefreak has learned how to properly design for the Switch.
titles: I've been around since Gen 1, and I'm thoroughly enjoying this game. But it has issues.

review_contents:
I've so far put 150 or so hours into Pokemon Shield and am planning on getting Sword as well. I'm not usually the type of player to buy both versions but I have been absolutely smitten by these titles. The wild area is fantastic and introduces so true MMO elements. The pokemon feel alive and vibrant; camping is a treat that introduces lovely animations for every mon, old and new. And for those who are into competitive PVP play, it's never been easier to get a competitive team together thanks to nature modifying items, an easy to grind battle tower, and the ability to get high IV dittos with minimum effort for breeding.

And the storyline is an absolute treat. I think as far as ingame play goes, this is my favorite story since Hoenn. The characters are likeable and 3 dimensional, and they really improved on the handholding aspect by allowing you to skip the usual tutorial bits early game. Definitely give this game a try if you have any interest in pokemon at all, it's amazing.
titles: Best games of the series to date

review_contents:
For casual players, this game is pretty awesome. I've played through Blue, Pearl, X, Omega Ruby, Sun and Ultra Moon. I've been playing this game since day 1 and haven't completed the main adventure yet because I've been distracted by the wild areas and real life. It's fun creating new teams with the challenge of only using NEW pokemon. I like the designs of many of them.

For the serious players, you'll probably have complaints about the absence of your favorite pokemon. Or nitpick some graphical details. Or have qualms about what new additions mean for competitive play. My personal main complaint is the lack of new mega pokemon --- but I've been complaining about that since Sun/Moon.

With that said, giving it 1 or "OMG I WISH I COULD GIVE IT ZERO" stars is a little extreme. Perhaps with future game updates, this could be a 5-star game...but what they've provided so far is a solid game.
titles: Needs More for 30 Year Old Players

review_contents:
It's a fine game, bought this as I have no attention span... and this was easy to understand real quick and sort of play in the background while I do other things. Finished the game in about a week (probably around 20 Hours) although I only played the main story line and didn't worry about whatever else there was to do.

I will say this though - the Pokemon in this game were a bit boring to be honest. They didn't start "looking" cool till the very end when I had them up to about level 60. And by that point the game is literally almost done. So for the majority of the game I was just HOPING I would catch or "evolve" a Pokemon that would "look" cool. And then towards the end the game did start getting extremely boring.... because it was just one identical battle after another. But... I finished it. Did it. Done with that. Moving on now.....

This game was okay.
I've played every main title Pokemon game that's come out, and if I were to compare them I would say...
There's less to do. Towns are small, there's less NPCs. Less Pokemon to catch.
Some of the functions of the game are really weird; for example, sometimes you'll start a battle and you'll go from standing in a town to standing in a grassy field.
When you battle a NPC they stand behind their Pokemon, which is cool, except then they'll dissapear whenever you use a move.
Things blink in and out of existence constantly in this game, really. The draw distance is non-existent.
The animations for the human characters is awful, with jerky movements and the same creepy-constant smile on the main character's face. The animations for the Pokemon is all over; some are awesome, most aren't.
There is awful lag if you try to play online, buy that doesn't really matter because the only thing to do online really is random trade.
I was worried the game would be too easy, but I think it's actually par the course for the series. If you build a team strategically you'll win easy, if you use only the Pokemon you like it might be more difficult. Still no hard mode, but who knows, maybe that'll be DLC?
This game could use a lot of DLC. Or maybe just another year in development. Did I have fun? Yeah. 60 bucks of fun? No. Maybe 30-40 bucks. Get the game on sale, used, or share with a friend.
Or skip it altogether and get one of the previous games; it'll have more to explore, more to do, and more Pokemon with nearly identical gameplay.
titles: TL;DR- It's okay, but not worth 60 bucks.

review_contents: WARNING!!! This is a great game, I would rate the game 4 stars. But the reason this is a 1 star review is POKEMON HOME. I just got Pokemon home, and was excited you could transfer from 3ds to switch. Finally a way to put your hard earned Pokemon into the newer games. I wanted to transfer all my Pok√©mon into into Pok√©mon sword, but once I did it MY POK√âMON GOT STUCK. YES, 16 DOLLARS FOR THIS IS NOT WORTH IT! You can only transfer Pok√©mon that are in the sword/shield Pok√©dex. I understand that the sword/shield Pok√©dex has some Pok√©mon in it from previous games, but I warn you I PLAYED FOR 5 YEARS AND I HAD ALL KINDS OF SHINYS AND LEGENDARYS. I HAD ALL OF THE EVENT POK√âMON. But I even watched a video on if Pok√©mon home actually worked. Probably only able to TRANSFER 1/10 OF THE LEGENDARYS! Even if you do get this overpriced app, search up if the Pok√©mon can be transferred into Pok√©mon home just to be safe. FIX THIS NINTENDO THIS IS A 10 YEAR OLD IDEA. I GARUNTEE THAT MILLIONS OF OTHER PEOPLE WILL BE COMPLAINING ABOUT THIS.

If your new to the Pok√©mon scene , then you may be seeing a lot of negative or 1 star reviews on this game. These are false reviews from people who refuse to buy, play or try out the game due to in game *changes* as compared to the older games. There is actually a reddit post calling for ‚ÄúHardcore fans‚Äù to spam this game with negative reviews as a form of boycotting Pok√©mon until they get the game the way it was in the past. However not all change is bad. The point of a new game is to add new features and this is what this game brought.

The graphics are amazing, music is well written and the new features makes this game well worth the purchase.
New to this game is Dynmaxing and Gigantamaxing your pokemon (almost like a new evolution form ).
You can also customize your player with clothing options similar to stores in Sun/Moon.
Trading & Battling is now much simpler as you can do it with a push of a button.
There is a common area called ‚Äúwild area‚Äù where a variety of Pok√©mon gather at different levels and you can Co-Op with other players to catch strong Pok√©mon.
Gym battles have unique styles to keep the game feeling fresh & after you complete the game, there is a post game story to go through as well as a battle tower.

This game is well worth the price. If interested, I would recommend checking YouTube reviews from video game credible sources such as : Arlo, AustinJohnPlays , Beatemups, RTG 85 & ProtoMario. These are real reviews from real people (not companies) who will actually show you the gameplay.

A lot of the reviews I‚Äôve read are from people who never tried out the game and are ‚Äúcomplaining‚Äù about in game issues that are not really. I would say just do your own research and make your own decision on whether or not this game is for you. Personally I loved playing this game, and I‚Äôve played through every Pok√©mon game since the 90‚Äôs but you may or may not have different tastes.

In 2020 an iOS/Android/switch app will be release so you can send your older Pok√©mon into the new game. This was done so people can experience and find new Pok√©mon rather then using old Pok√©mon and never trying out the new Pok√©mon that were made available.
titles: Decide for yourself as I did.

review_contents:
While there are glaring issues with the game, Overall sword and shield are really great pokemon games. As someone who's owned every game since pokemon silver (Almost 20 years ago) this ranks as my #3 right behind Pokemon Platinum and Black/White 2. Don't be discouraged by the 1* reviews (Almost all of them don't have a verified purchase) because this game is well worth the 60$ price tag.

The biggest issues are the story (It's a pokemon game so the story is almost always lack luster), Frame rate issues due to the switch, Incomplete pokedex, and some textures being very poorly done.

The biggest pros: The open world and overworld sprites of pokemon give you an experience you never thought you could have when playing a mainline pokemon game. Trade evolutions can now be found in the wild, Shiny hunting is leagues easier, Customization is finally at a place I'm happy with, Overall generation pokemon designs are really nice, A large portion of new gen 8 pokemon are competitively viable, Animation overhauls on old moves and new animations are very good, Did I mention it's a freaking openworld pokemon game?

Despite what all the extremely nitpicky people are saying (and I‚Äôm nitpicky myself, so that‚Äôs saying something), I‚Äôm actually enjoying this game.
It has some decent music at some points, and I haven‚Äôt had any noticeably likable music in Pok√©mon since the original Gold and Silver came out way back when.
I‚Äôm a LONGTIME Pok√©mon fan, from way back in ‚Äò97, and I typically get the games at some point because I still enjoy the game mechanics despite the story and all of that. I love the competitive breeding and battling aspects.
The graphics are decent in the this game (I honestly felt LGPE was lacking for a Switch title, fully-priced). I rolled my eyes so hard when I heard about them introducing Dynamaxing but it actually turned out to be somewhat interesting.
I was one of the people who wears pretty upset about the lack of a National Dex in this entry (and am still disappointed). I don‚Äôt think what they HAVE introduced in this game makes up for not having over half of the Pok√©mon allowed into the game, especially if they‚Äôve supposedly been working on this title since around, or even before, USUM. I feel what they did in this aspect is just pure cash-grabbery and laziness.

Otherwise, I feel this game is entertaining enough and I like enough of the new Pok√©mon to give it a few stars. I personally think most of the Genwunners are way too whiny and entitled when it comes to what they expect from the main title games. I‚Äôm technically part of that group I guess, but I still don‚Äôt like that attitude. I agree they could‚Äôve added more of what people actually wanted included, and the new mechanics aren‚Äôt equal to what was lost, but it‚Äôs still an alright game.

My toddler especially likes playing it and has his own file. It‚Äôs perfect for kids who‚Äôve maybe played the last couple generations or so of the main title Pok√©mon games.
titles: People are far too critical and that‚Äôs coming from someone who is extremely critical themselves....

review_contents: My son received the Pokemon Sword edition as a gift and he loves it. He said it was great seeing wild Pokemon wandering around in the grass at the same time you can still find random pocket monsters. It really added more life to the world he explored, especially in the wild areas. He said when he first stepped into the open areas, he couldn't stop exploring even when the Pokemon he encountered were stronger than the ones on his team! He said he also liked how it had some top-down levels at the same time it had the wild areas with the free camera. It added more variety to the game. He and I both love England and its culture so he really liked how the Galar Region was similar to it! He wanted to add that he saw that the graphics weren't amazing and saw how some people didn't like it, but the graphics were fine and is still beautiful in certain areas. He said his favorite thing so far is the Pokemon camp where you can play with your Pokemon and even make soup! Oh, and he really enjoys the big "Dynamax" Pokemon battles! He said if you like Pokemon, you should at least give this game a shot!
titles: My son loves it and he can't stop playing it!!

review_contents:
I gave my 7yo this game for Christmas. It's January 4th and she's already completed it, and that's with us forcing her to take breaks. The battles all seem incredibly easy, as if it's hard to fail, as is progressing through the main story.

She enjoyed the novelty of catching Pokemon while it lasted.

As a parent I am disappointed in:
- How short the story is
- How easy it is to progress
- How easy the battles are
- How irritating the constantly fast paced music is
- That there is a stat system that's never explained and basically had no significant role

This is a $30 game at a $60 price point.

She played Pokemon Crystal from 2000 for ten times longer.
titles: Short and not challenging at all

review_contents: I've been playing pokemon games since the first ones that came out on the game boy and game boy color. There are a lot of people that are upset that their favorite pokemon is not in this game, but that doesn't mean that this game is bad or that it deserves a 1 star rating. I've put in 47 hours into the game so far and only have about half of the badges and caught half of the 400 pokemon available. This game is my favorite pokemon game yet, the graphics are great and the music is amazing. I highly recommend playing this game, you can spend countless hours just in the wild areas filling up your pokedex.

I have to say, this is a first for me. I have loved all of the pokemon games up till now, but now it is impossible to not see behind the curtain. This game was a huge disappointment, the animations are terrible, the story is the worst so far (which is saying something as they have all been pretty generic), the pokemon are some of the lamest in years, the "dynamic weather" systems are laughable and can literally change in single steps breaking immersion, pop in is everywhere and even in cities with npcs which is inexcusable, models are reused EVERYWHERE which wouldnt be bad but they literally have 2 tree models in the entire wild area and they literally look like crappy copy pastes all over the world, the national DeX isnt supported (which I would even SUPPORT if they had quality animations for the new pokemon but they definitely DO NOT), the gyms are cool at first then get lazy near the end, end game content is nonexistent, online matchmaking does NOT work, and all of this from the literal LARGEST MEDIA FRANCHISE EVER and their mainline game no less!!!! This is sad. This is beyond disappointing. This game is literally only good for children who have never played the games, and even then at 60$ you can get so much better games for your children that foster so much more. Skip this game and use the money for better experiences.

I'm a long time Pok√©mon fan that started playing back in Gen 2. This is an amazing game despite the complaints of the hard-core Dexit group.

Story:
Does this game have an incredible story? Not really, but it's Pok√©mon. Play some other RPG if that's what you want.

Feel:
This game really captures the feel of living in the Pok√©mon world more than any other game before it. The overworld Pokemon, the wild area, and camping is a great touch that makes all the Pok√©mon feel much more alive.

Quality of life improvements:
There are a lot of little quality of life improvements that make things so much better for me and less grindy. And there are little things that make it easier and faster to build competitive Pok√©mon.

1. You can swap your party at any point.
You don't have to go back to a Pokemon center box.

2. Everyone in the party gets exp after you KO a Pok√©mon. It makes it easier to level up Pok√©mon.

3. There's a move learner and Pokemon renamer at every Pokemon center.

4. Poke Jobs are a new thing you can send your Pok√©mon on for a number of hours and they come back with a lot of exp.

5. Breeding has been updated where you don't have to wait generations in breeding to give your Pokemon egg moves. You can pass moves between parents now.

6. If your Pokemon doesn't have perfect Individual Values, you don't have to breed one. In the post game, you can earn bottle caps to increase your Pokemon's IVs through hyper training (Pok√©mon must be level 100).

7. You now can change your Pok√©mon's nature with mints.

8. Max Raid battles award Exp candies that can level up Pok√©mon really fast (so you can get your Pok√©mon hyper trained faster).

9. The Hammerlock University courses give you an option to EV train Pok√©mon automatically.

All in all, these changes make the game feel very polished for a semi-competitive player like me.

Max Raid Battles:
I was skeptical of these at first, but I have grown to like them. I now really like hitting the Max Raid battles to get loot. The Exp candies are very useful and you can get a lot of good moves on your Pok√©mon from the TR loot.

Max Raid battles are best when you have a friend playing with you. It's a nice touch that Pok√©mon now has a cooperative mode. My brother-in-law and I have spent hours doing Max Raid battles and hunting for rare G-Max Pok√©mon forms.
titles: An amazing game that I will be playing for a long time

review_contents: This is perhaps the worst Pok√©mon game ever made. It‚Äôs a lacking in every way shape and form. It feels like no real effort was put into this game. The storyline is terrible and lacks any imagination. If you‚Äôre considering buying this game don‚Äôt. Go buy a 3DS and play those Pok√©mon games because they are leagues better than whatever this was trying to be. And not allowing all the old Pok√©mon to be able to be in this game is just lazy. If this is where the game franchise is headed, and putting expansion packs for extra money for a game that was severely lacking. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll be buying anymore Pok√©mon games.

The biggest standout for me is the new Pok√©mon, I know it‚Äôs just my opinion but they all seem so cool and creative and fun! Like seriously it‚Äôs hard to plan out my team when I wanna catch everything! Being a huge Godzilla fan I really like the giant Pok√©mon aspect as well! The graphics are really colorful and they really pop out on your tv! I would also recommend playing on your tv! The soundtrack has been really good! I have not felt compelled to turn off the music like in previous games! The only downside I can truly think of is that sometimes the story bits can drag on longer than an adult veteran player would care for I‚Äôm sure! But maybe is still necessary for younger and or newer fans. Regarding the lack of the complete Pok√©mon list, does not bother me really because I never sought out to ‚Äúcatch them all‚Äù I‚Äôm just here to have fun. In conclusion I would highly recommend this game to anyone, not just Pok√©mon fans but anyone who owns a switch and loves video games!
titles: Lots of fun and fantastic monster designs

review_contents: This game is amazing!! It‚Äôs my first Pok√©mon game so I guess for nostalgic long time fans it might have been a disappointment but for me it was super fun!! Most of the negative reviews I‚Äôve read are from disappointed long time fans which is always expected from games like this but I can definitely recommend it for new players!! Even though it wasn‚Äôt incredibly challenging it was a cool story and catching different Pok√©mon and befriending them and training them is awesome. There‚Äôs so much to explore in the vast wild area and the local multiplayer aspect is so cool. The graphics are amazing too. I‚Äôve put so many hours into the game and continue to play even after I‚Äôve beaten the story mode bc there‚Äôs so much more you can do.
titles: Maybe not for nostalgic players but as a new player I love it

review_contents: This is the worst pokemon game ever, nintendo 3ds graphics, and it feels lackluster in general, I just wanted to catch squirtle in the game, I guess that's not gonna happen

This game is so short there's nothing to fill between gyms you can literally reach your next gym in 10 minutes and just shotgun thru the whole game in under a day. There's no significant story line and really no real quests. Don't waste your time and money

The game has great graphics and looks beautiful to me. People will hate on it because of the 'lazy animations' and not including half the dex but I don't really care! At its core it's a pok√©mon game and it clearly had some effort put into the characters and game setting. I love the wild areas and all the new quality of life improvements they added.

I was part of the people who thought it would be bad and was complaining about lack of content and yadda yadda, but once I got hold of the game I couldn't put it down! I'd say give it a try even if your expectations are super high.
titles: Great so far despite what everyone has said!

review_contents:
It‚Äôs a cute little game with some fun twist and turns and amazing new Pok√©mon. The gym challenge was a great change from the normal battling gyms pace. I feel the story was cute, but could have been better as I felt it was rushed at the end.

The wild area is an amazing addition to the game and has kept me busy for hours on end. I do wish the scenery was a little more diverse like breath of the wilds, but it‚Äôs still a fun change of pace. I do wish that the wild area would have replaced routes as traveling back to the wild area was a little pace breaking during the story, though.

My only major complaint I have about this game is the lack of post game content. Most of the newer first version Pok√©mon games have little to no end game content because they want you to buy the upgraded new version coming out in the following years; however, this game doesn‚Äôt even have any legendaries to catch right now besides the box legendary. Which is super disappointing because that was part of the thrill of post game.

More legendaries will prob be included as max raid battles, but I will miss having legendaries be apart of the overworld and having a little side quest to find and capture them.

So overall a fun game with nothing ground breaking. If you liked recent titles like Pok√©mon sun and moon and x and y you‚Äôll enjoy this game well enough.
titles: It‚Äôs a pretty standard Pok√©mon game

review_contents:
I'm a couple of hours into this and I feel like it's a great game. But then I remember that this is supposed to be a home console game, yet it is nothing more than a really good looking handheld game. This is run on the same system that ran Breath of the Wild & L.A. Noire, yet it still feels like a 3DS game. Some animations look really good, however most don't.

It's very linear and your told where to go all the time. Everytime you enter and leave a town your interrupted by annoying cutscenes and characters.

There is no challenge. Most trainers you encounter will only have one or two weak Pokemon that you will blow through very easy. While you're in between towns you will encounter plenty of NPC who will heal your Pokemon for you. You're given an escape rope that has unlimited uses, even though the cave areas are tiny.

Pokemon wasn't ready for a home console game yet.

Played pokemon since the very first generation. This game is completely halfhearted and disappointing. Beyond 64% of existing pokemon being cut out of the game, the problems are all around. Max raids dont work AND require a paid subscription. PVP is shallow and consists of about 12 pokemon that are competitive. Bad texture rendering and braindead dialog make you feel like you are playing an n64 era game. For every good music track, there are 2 that make you feel like having a stroke. All said, wish i saved my money. Maybe actually try next time gamefreak.
titles: You may be tempted, but resist. This game is worth 35 to 40 dollars at best...

review_contents: First of all do not listen to a lot of the negative reviews on here. This game is getting review bombed on multiple websites because of the controversy regarding the dex (you can search about it online). You can also see they did not purchase the game next to their username. Is this game perfect ? No. But this game is really good if you look past the story and the limited number of Pok√©mon‚Äôs available at launch. This game is 7/10 in my books. But not 1/10 like a lot of people are saying. They are just upset. Judge it for yourself

It's no secret their a lot of butt hurt people on the internet. But don't let them shame you into missing out on these games. The games look amazing. The new Pokemon are awsome. Their alot of old Pokemon returning and the variety of Pokemon in the game is some of the best in the series. The wild area is fun to explore and has a lot to do. Dynatmax is an amazing feature and the boss type battles that come from it are addicting. All in all the game is amazing and one of the finest entry in the series. Don't let the man babies decide if you should by this game or not. If you do you're missing out
titles: Don't listen to the review bombers. Pokemon Sword and Shield are a another amazing entry

review_contents:
hey.. I totally understand why people are sad if they've been playing the game since the original red/green and if they've been using pokemon bank. It's lame because Nintendo made promises on their pokemon bank, says you will be able to travel with your pokemon in every generation by using the bank.

However, as someone who does not use pokemon bank, and does not really care about having 600+ pokemon in a single game, I think it's an awesome game so far. The graphics are not perfect, but a huge upgrade from Sun/Moon.
titles: I understand why people are sad..

review_contents: So they cut the amount of pokemon you can catch in half. How sad. No longer the game it was, the variety is pathetic. Loved getting all the past starters and they removed all but the original trio.
titles: Cut rate, dont buy til price drop

review_contents: This game is half the length, half the size, and 50 % more expensive than the previous versions and is sold incomplete. The other half of the game is another $30 taking to grand total to $90 where the previous versions were $4D. On top of all this, they say that it's because of balancing and they aren't making a 3rd special version. BS, the DLC has to be purchased on both versions for a grand total of $180. I could buy 3 versions before and only pay $120 total. Complete ripoff and exploitation of their customer base.
titles: Absolute worst ripoff in Pok√©mon history

review_contents:
the only reason I gave it two stars instead of one is it's still pokemon and if you like pokemon you can't completely hate it. however, it IS the worst pokemon gen game to date.

The story line was stupid, the game felt rushed, it felt very redundant and recycled (for example, you have to fight all the gym leaders to get the badges then fight them again before fighting the final champ), your rival is a little pansy with no confidence, pokemon are way too easy to find and catch, pokemon are way to easy to level up (I had a lvl 100 pokemon along with everyone else in the 60's before fighting the final champ. I could have got them all waaaaay higher too!), and many other things.

What happen to the days where there was real urgency? back then team rocket was well threaded into the game. They ran a casino, you had to infiltrate their hideout, the 8th badge was their leader....and your old rival Gary. he was awesome and actually good. He had confidence and was known through the pokemon series as one of the best trainers. The guy you have now is creepy....

I can go on and on about how whack this game is. I still recommend it though bc it's pokemon.
titles: Worst Gen So Far And Here Is Why...

review_contents: The internet is nuts. Sure, it is lacking slightly in the National Dec factor, but it is overall an amazing game. To state some good parts, dynamaxing, all though it is a basic feature, give a feeling of satisfaction when you are the one dynamaxing. Also, uncovering of the story of the darkest day as you go along is like solving a crime. Three, being able to see the Pok√©mon in the grass simulates being there. Finally, having the gyms be a region-wide competition adds a competitive feel to the game. Cons: beating the gyms is a kind of easy if you catch an advantaged type Pok√©mon. (Example: if the next gym is a dragon gym, and you grind to get an ice type). There also is less Pok√©mon than in other titles. The storyline is a little crazy. In conclusion, this a great game, and I recommend it to anyone who has a switch.
You‚Äôre basically buying an unfinished and mediocre game for $60. Worst Pok√©mon in the mainline. It‚Äôs missing so much content and it still has the 3DS graphics. Pathetic

I've been playing Pok√©mon for a very long time. As a long time fan of the series, I feel that Sword/Shield is a worth while game. I seriously had a of fun during my playthrough, and the new wild area is pretty incredible to see for the first time. I also really liked the new Pok√©mon designs., and the Max Raid battles. Despite not having a complete National Dex, there was still a great verity of Pok√©mon to catch and build a balanced team with. The characters, and story weren't all that bad either. It's a really good Pok√©mon game. The big issue with the game is that everything felt extremely linear. Going from gym to gym had a VERY set path, and there wasn't much room to explore around the world freely (other than the wild area). The linearity nearly ruined my experience. The routes felt really small as well, only adding to the frustration of feeling boxed in. The other issue I had was that you can't turn off experience share, and every Pok√©mon leveled up extremely fast. It would of been nice to have that option to turn EX Share off for harder playthroughs. If your a fan of Pok√©mon, I would highly recommend Sword/Shield. It;s a fun experience...Just go into it knowing it won't be perfect. 3.6 out of 5 stars

I have been playing Pok√©mon since I was nine years old when it came out for the original Gameboy(Red and Blue.) This game is absolute nostalgia. If you are a Pok√©mon fan, a newbie, or someone who might want to get back into the series. Do yourself a favor and just buy it. I bought it for my nine year old daughter yesterday and she can barely let it down... Also playing/watching on dock mode on the big screen is just absolutely amazing.

People are bombing the reviews out of principle because not all Pokemon made it into this game. They are refusing to buy it and making things up to prevent others from buying it.

I was worried after reading their reviews, but figured I would actually try it. I like it a lot better then Sun and Moon. Really fun game.
titles: Reviews are being bombed by people with mostly unverified purchases

review_contents: I can't believe I spent $60 on this boring game. All I want is a game where I can catch and train Pokemon. This game has too much boring dialogue and worthless side quests that you can't skip over. Also, none of the Pokemon are worth catching. In my opinion, they're ugly and keep getting weirder looking. Where are the pretty Pokemon such as Umbreon and Espeon, Growlithe and Vulpix? What a waste.

Been playing Pok√©mon since Red and Blue on the original Gameboy. I was completely disappointed with the amount of features, especially postgame, with this title. You would think for a premium price of 60 dollars this long awaited Pok√©mon game would blow you away. The icing on the cake for me is when they announced the Expansion Pass. So now not only do you pay 60 bucks for a game with less content, but you have to spend 30 MORE dollars to get the full experience. No thank you Gamefreak.

Very short, bland and low quality Pokemon game. It is definitely not worth $60. It uses graphics from the 3DS and has many bugs in gameplay, it can even fry your Switch and all other games save files. It only has about 40% of existing Pokemon available. It is very tutorial and baby proofed feeling the entire game. Way too easy. Characters are annoying and constantly interrupt gameplay. Many graphical shortcomings and poor quality graphics.

I've been a Pokemon fan since Red and Blue, then Yellow, Gold and Silver, then I probably picked up Crystal or Sapphire but didn't get the chance to finish it. Anyway, I was able to play Pokemon Lets Go Eevee recently and this is the first time I am playing a main series game on the switch.

I just really love that the graphics and animations are way improved now compared to GBA. The concept that gym battles are like major sports events in this region makes you hyped up , too. Music is awesome.

This is my sister's first time playing Pokemon and she's loving it so far. I may have to buy her a Switch lite for Christmas so we don't have to compete for play time. Now I'm thinking of throwing Pokemon Shield and Let's Go Pikachu for her so we could trade exclusives.

I understand the hardcore fans wishing there were more features and I'm all for that. I hope that will come as an update or an expansion. But that doesn't take away the fun from playing this game. This remains a joy to play.

I am 33 years old, my son is 6 years old. When we first started playing we played 3 hours straight, he seems really into the game and he was able to read most of the dialogues, items, and menus thanks to the simple but enthusiastic writing. But now he needs to wait until I beat the game because I can't stop playing this thing and I am taking the switch with me for my daily subway commute. Sorry son! I am almost done. - Best dad.

I legit find it funny that this game got so much hate. Like there‚Äôs literally a two paragraph review from someone who didn‚Äôt buy the game because amazon tells you if they purchased the item and the review was posted the day the game came out.

I can't believe that I almost listened to all of the negative reviews out there telling me not to buy this game. I've been playing since Pokemon Yellow, and this game is one of my top three favorites I've ever played. The character personalization is great, as are the graphics and open-world feel of the gameplay. The fact that you can see the Pokemon in the grass is also a game changer. Overall, this game has far exceeded the expectations that I had for it, especially given the large amount of negative reviews. The only negative things that I personally have to say about it are that 1. I wish the challenge level were higher because I miss the days of the rival actually being difficult. 2. I wish the storyline were more engaging.

Seriously, though-- buy this game if you're considering it. I loved it and am so glad that I didn't listen to the other reviews. I've already put in 35 hours and only just now finished the main storyline.
titles: Great game! Don't listen to negative reviews

review_contents:
I play pokemon all the way to blue and red and it's always i enjoy them. I can see how sword and shield did poorly however, keep this in mind that the developers had one target and it's for children not for adult which is why you see alot of reused pokemon kids will see and recognize overrated pokemon like pikachu, charizard, evee, ect. I'm not say there bad pokemon there just icons you see the most.
It's a good game it has a semi good story and a easy to level up but, keep this in mind its targeted to children and makes it easy for them I understand those who cherish the game and transfer there pokemon from game to game I been there and sure I was disappointed but at least it opens my options to more then my main party.
Regardless I stand neutral to his game it's perfect for beginning and those who are just getting into pokemon; horrible for those who are mainstream and go extreme hard core on the game .
titles: Pokemon sword and shield had its differences

review_contents: They fixed several issues the franchise has had, at the expense of pretty much everything else. The majority of the characters and plot are terrible even for a Pokemon game. The online rarely lets you connect to other players doing raids. The graphics and animations range from amazing to absolute trash. The Wild Area feels like its an open world... until you realize you can't catch most of the pokemon until you get gym badges. Catching pokemon is still fun, some of the gym challenges are ok, and you don't have to grind much especially if you do a lot of raid battles. This game will not challenge you in any way, unless you impose rules on yourself. If you connect to the internet you will lag a lot. Overall it isn't a terrible game... but it's not good or fun either.

Yes, I understand the issue that many Hardcore pokemon fans have with the game.
- Many pokemon from previous generations were cut.
- Graphics aren't as good as they should be (but it's still the best looking pokemon game ever)
- Plenty of recycled content from the 3DS games.

With all that said, this game still has over 400 pokemon in it and plenty to experience. Just don't expect that revolutionary jump in terms of gameplay and features. The game will give you 100+ hours of content if you choose to fill out the whole pokedex. The most important thing is that the game is still fun at it's core and anyone who's played pokemon before will enjoy it as long as your expectations aren't sky high.
titles: Yes this game has it's issues for hardcore fans but it's still a blast for the casual Pokemon gamer.

review_contents: The game is ‚Äúfun‚Äù but not $60 dollars worth fun. This game should have been $39.99 tops. The game graphics are nice. But this is definitely the worst Pokemon game I‚Äôve ever played. The game feels rush and not finish. The story writing is awful and just lazy. The game gives you everything so easily, from rare candies to XP boosters that are extremely easy to get. You are basically boosted from start till end of game. Very disappointed.

This game was fun and beautiful. The story was fantastic and the Wildlands were really fun. I have played pokemon a long time and I am going to have a blast introducing the kids in my life to pokemon with this game.

As horrible as this game is from a technical standpoint I feel that I was unfair to call it "the death of Pokemon as a franchise" in my initial review of it. I enjoyed it, and it's perfectly okay to have guilty pleasures. You don't have to hate this game just because tons of people do, you can have as much fun as you want with it as long as you don't ignore the glaring flaws (sketchy animation quality, lack of animations despite the promise of there being new ones, 30$ DLC less than a few months after release that could've just been included with the base game if they took a bit more time to program the damn thing, ect.) in the end I feel my first score of 4/10 was unjust and due to fun factor I will increase my score for this game to a solid 6/10. Not fantastic but perfect for someone who wants to get into the franchise.
titles: I was a little too harsh on this game

review_contents: Rushed and lacking content

The game suffers from lag, short stort, and a lack of pokemon. I dont understand why people praise this game you get ripoffed buying this game 60 dollars and a small amount of content makes no sense. I love pokemon ive played every version since the early 2000s. But this game is by far the laziest edition to the saga. I bought game game for 35 dollars from gamestop thank you swagbucks
titles: Lazy game equals alot of money

review_contents: I have been playing pokemon games all my life, playing every one of the main series games. This entry captures the joy I haven't felt since I was child. It is truly a masterpiece and definitely deserves a play on any switch.
titles: It's a breath of fresh air!

review_contents: As far as Pokemon games go, this is a level of disrespect and carelessness that has yet to be seen. Clunky mechanics, lazy graphics, and a story that could have been written by a 5-year old. The Dynamax mechanic is cheap and unentertaining. If you need an example of why this game is bad, just try to find the stamp you are looking for in an online connection. It doesn't exist. Gamefreak did everyone wrong with this game. Don't waste your money. Play a good pokemon game.

I was initially skeptical, what with the rumors of the game developers lying to the audience around the National Pok√©dex, but I must say ‚Äî I love this game. I'm about halfway through and I have thoroughly enjoyed most every moment of playtime. I'd recommend picking it up if you don't care about transferring "legacy" Pok√©mon from previous games! It's a lot of fun!
So many steps back for every step forward, big disapointment
This game is so much fun! I'm really enjoying it so far. I'm 3x gyms down and having a lot fun playing it on the weekends. The world is a lot of fun, I love the new Pokemon, and its paced well.
Better than the last few entries for pokemon. Highly recommend.

Made a great gift for my nephew (niece got Shield). They did victory laps around the house as soon as they saw what they were.

I haven't done or played anything Pokemon related in over a decade, but I watched them play for a bit and it's basically the game I grew up with in HD. If you liked the old games, you'll probably like this. Your kids will DEFINITELY love this.
titles: I'm the favorite uncle for a month

review_contents: This for the most part has been the game I wanted to play since I was 11 when I first received Pokemon Red for Game Boy Original.
Good Story Over All Fun Game, Disappointed by lack of national dex and the graphics could be better

While this game has received a lot of hate for not having the complete national dex available, it is captivating and amazing. I have not had this much excitement and fun with a Pok√©mon game since X and Y. It is sad you can‚Äôt have all your favorite Pok√©mon, but it‚Äôs still an amazing game nonetheless. Don‚Äôt let all the negative reviews discourage you from buying.

Love it! Shame not all the mons are in it but let's be honest, no one cares if ratatta isn't in it or a stupid Weedle. Game is beautiful and the new mechanic of dynamaxing is so much better than the terrible z moves in sun and moon. It's great, don't bother listening to these grown men crying about the Pokedex, I would recommend it;
It's all been said before, look at the other 1 star reviews.

Fun, new, and exciting. This game is the best if you go into it not knowing what the new Pok√©mon are. It does have some flaws, but so does every other Pok√©mon game. It has new features, like camping, curry making, the wild area, and other things.
Can‚Äôt get Champion Leon‚Äôs cape
Lazy game design. Not worth the price of a full price switch game, just replay an older game for a better game with more features.

1) The graphics in this game are beautiful
2) The storyline is amazing and fun
3) This game has all of the best parts of the older games mixed in with great improvements.

I got sword for myself, and shield for my girlfriend. We play pokemon GO together, but the last pokemon game I've played was white. We love this game, its super fun!! Super surprised we can raid and trade together offline.
i'm not mad at all about the whole "pokedex cut" everyone was going on about,i had an amazing time playing thru an astounding looking game with unique pokemon filling the place!

Gamefreak is lazy. Wait and buy used if you really wanna experience this game. It's Pokemon, sure, but it'd be nice if gamefreak put some effort and creativity into the series instead of just lazily pushing out the bare minimum knowing people will still eat it up.
titles: Whether lazy devs or rushed development, game is mediocre.

review_contents: Awful animations for a next-gen Nintendo system. Basically feels as I am playing a 3ds version of this game. I am quite disappointed that they put little effort into this. It's 2019! Besides that, the gameplay overall is ok. I like the new wilderness area in that one can encounter level 60 pokemon just an hour into the game, thus posing a new level of difficulty.
titles: Decent Gameplay but Awful Graphics & Animations

review_contents:
Glitches, graphics are a joke, less Pok√©mon, overall lazy and rush work.

Highlight: soundtrack is good

Loved it. Storyline could be better but as for the new region with the ability to catch 400 pokes. The wild area theres plenty to do. I couldn't put it down. Finally beat the champ and now filling the pokedex

Don‚Äôt let haters fool you, this is an awesome game. Yes the NationalDex was cut, and I wish there was voice acting, but this is still a great Pokemon title. Beautiful graphics, great music, addictive gameplay. GrookeyGang for life.
Brings back the excitement from Red & Blue. Must own game for the Switch. 10/10
Great pokemon game that's a fun experience for all who play no matter the age and is definitely worth a play!
Ive been a pokemon player since I was in 3rd grade. I am now 24 years old. This is by far the WORST pokemon game ive ever played and is an insult to the franchise. IF IT AINT BROKE DONT FIX IT!!!!
I‚Äôm so disappointed by this game. It felt so empty, unfinished, and utterly forgettable.!I still remember Pok√©mon yellow, gold and silver and can‚Äôt believe they created such a lame of a game.
Im in love with this game looks great and plays great
The grandson loves this game and was so happy on Christmas when he opened it
Pokemon... However lose one star because you kept overplayed Charizard but no Bulbasaur....
Product as advertised. Got here quickly
It‚Äôs much better Pok√©mon and Let‚Äôs go Pikachu
titles: It‚Äôs much better Pok√©mon and Let‚Äôs go Pikachu

review_contents: Just a good little chill experience, the game still has good pokemon vibes!

review_contents: Top 5 pokemon game.

My daughter (age 9) got really into Pokemon about a year ago, leading us to playing Pokemon Let‚Äôs Go Eevee. She‚Äôs been obsessed with the franchise ever since.

Sword and Shield is a different entry into the series. Instead of a top-down, closed path game, you‚Äôre presented with a wide open world to explore, catch pokemon, and take on trainer battles.

It‚Äôs big, brightly colored, and just lovely to run around and experience. One of the biggest annoyances with ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Go‚Äù was the pace of movement, and just getting around felt like a chore. Travel in Sword/Shield feels much better, and the freedom of movement and not being locked out of paths is great.

Everything else about the game follows the same basic Pokemon gameplay: catch pokemon, train them up, and battle other trainers.

There‚Äôs been some controversy about the size the pokedex (the amount of pokemon in-game), but as a more casual fan/player, there‚Äôs not really much to say. I‚Äôm sure it will be a big deal for hardcore fans, but they will still sink 100+ hours into this game.

Differences from Pokemon Shield:
As with most pokemon games it‚Äôs broken up into two difference versions, each with very minor exclusive pokemon included. Honestly, very few people will care which they get. The game is exactly the same with a couple minor differences. According to other sources here they are:

Sword exclusive pokemon:
Deino, Zweilous, Hydreigon, Jangmo-o, Hakamo-o, Kommo-o, Gothita, Gothorita, Gothitelle, Rufflet, Braviary, Mawile, Solrock, Passimian, Turtonator, Galarian Sirfetch‚Äôd, Galarian Darmanitan, Galarian Darumaka, Flapple

Shield exclusive pokemon:
Larvitar, Pupitar, Tyranitar, Goomy, Sliggoo, Goodra, Solosis, Duosion, Reuniclus, Vullaby, Mandibuzz, Sableye, Lunatone, Oranguru, Drampa, Galarian Ponyta, Galarian Rapidash, Glaraian Corsola, Cursola, and Appleton

There‚Äôs also supposed to be a difference in some of the gym leaders, and potentially in which Legendary Pokemon are featured, but these are minor, and only the most hardcore fans are going to care either way which they get. Obviously I haven‚Äôt caught them all, but if the above is important to you, make sure you pick the right version!
titles: Sword is an absolutely wonderful experience: big, bright, playful, and fun!

review_contents: For a $20 price increase from previous games, you would expect more features to be added. Instead, far more content was removed from previous games than actually added in this one. The supposed reason for the cut content and price increase was the increase in graphics quality, but the game runs poorly and the animations are limited. Online services are locked behind Nintendo Online's paywall. You can't bring over all of your Pokemon from previous games, and you have to pay for another service to import the few that were included.

Pok√©mon Sword and Shield are very similar to the previous titles on the Nintendo 3DS in the general way the game plays.

The standout portion of the game for me is the wild area; an open world inspired area with different biomes, weather, and lots of Pok√©mon walking around the overworld. This is what I imagine Pok√©mon on a home console should be, but in these games it is limited to one area that‚Äôs more or less separate from the main route you travel on your adventure. An interesting component of this zone is the max raid battles, which were inspired directly from Pok√©mon GO. I do not like the forced multiplayer in PGO, but in this game I was happy to learn you do not need multiple players the game will spawn NPCs to help you.

It‚Äôs too soon to tell what they may do with this game going forward, but I think the lack of DLC is a huge miss. These two games, unlike their 3DS/NDS/GB counterparts, do not contain programming for every existing Pok√©mon. Meaning the creatures that can‚Äôt be caught in these two games, can‚Äôt even be traded from previous games. Knowing Pok√©mon their resolution to this will be to keep making games, presumably $60 a piece $120 for both versions like these. I just feel with the higher price of a switch game compared to the 3DS this is going to become much less practical.

3/5. I‚Äôm not overly bothered with the lack of so many Pok√©mon, it‚Äôs disappointing with their track record, but in general the game has a lot of fun elements to it. The part that I find the most disappointing is the setup being basically the 3DS game running at a higher resolution with higher fidelity assets. I didn‚Äôt expect a ‚Äúbreath of the wild‚Äù for Pok√©mon, but aside from art assets they aren‚Äôt taking advantage of the increased power they have from the 3DS. If the next Pok√©mon game on switch doesn‚Äôt massively overhaul the formula I probably won‚Äôt buy it, but that‚Äôs only coming after I have played the newest games and realize there‚Äôs more they could do and they played it a little too safe here.

Don't look at the review bombers, this game is an excellent social experience. The Wild Area is just scratching the surface of what the future is of Pokemon and has our family excited. Graphics wise the game looks beautiful and some of the new animations are really breath taking. Only complaint really is the control changes between the Routes and Wild Area. Really looking forward to the upcoming expansions to get even more enjoyment out of the game!
Horrible game. Less than 12 hours of gameplay. We beat the game in 3 days. No end game content. I was expecting something at least as good as previous Pokemon games
Almost twice the price for half the content. It seems the budget went to the stellar music and quality of life changes... Wouldn't recommend as a full priced game.
titles: Nowhere near enough bang for your buck

Our grandson opened the Super Mario Odyssey present on Christmas morning, and the CASE WAS EMPTY. It did not contain the electronic game! One star rating is the lowest option, but obviously it should be ZERO.

I love this game. I have not yet completed it but I do have 700+ stars, so I'm far enough in to know most of the important features. The game is basically a love letter to all of the games that came before (especially Super Mario 64), and it's beautiful to boot. If you like Mario, you obviously like this game.

review_contents: Great game that brought me back to the good ole days of Mario Sunshine on the Gamecube. Anyone can play and it's super chill. Highly recommend it to anyone who likes a laid back game.

I'm typically a PC gamer and love the open world games like FarCry and Just Cause. Those games are great, but they get your adrenaline running and sometimes you just want to relax. This game is just that. It's genuine relaxing fun. Every time I play this game I end my gaming session feeling happy, not tired. It's wonderful

To be perfectly honest, I have never played this game. I watched videos on YouTube and decided to purchase for my 12-year-old son along with the Switch console. I am usually a very meticulous buyer, but this time I made a slight mistake. Whilst looking for the cheapest price, I purchased the UK version. This was completely my error. I was dismayed at first, but then became excited that I had an import!!! So, if you are an American who purchased by mistake and are having buyer's remorse.......DON'T! This is no different from the North American release. Do you speak English? Yup, methinks you are good to go then. Now, I haven't opened the game yet, but I think my rating will stand unless there is no game inside. lol Not kidding! Also..I researched DLC info for you. It seems numerous people have bought games from different regions and were still able to purchase DLCs from their regions without any problems. The Switch seems to care more about your System language than a specific region that speaks said language. Example.....buy the Japanese version of this game. Since it supportsw English, and your System language is English too......you can download any future DLC from any English speaking region. Oh yeah......game came in two days, mint condition, etc. Again...I just need to open it. If there's no game...i'll be cranky. lol

Mario Odyssey is solid addition to the 3D Mario games, and an exemplary Nintendo Switch game.
In this new adventure, Cappy helps Mario supernaturally embody living and inanimate objects in a delightfully playful cartoon manner. Most missions use Cappy's ability to become enemies and such to overcome the puzzle-like environments. Cappy can also be controller by Player 2.
The art is very crisp and colorful and each world's themes are focused and interesting. Objectives are diverse and often challenging. The game can be very easy to pick up as a new player, yet there is a layer of complexity that invites hardcore players to pull off some calculated acrobatics and maneuvers. There are also references and sections of the game that anyone that grew up with Mario will enjoy.
The story is reminiscent of Pixar shorts and takes Mario's cast of characters through different large worlds to rescue the princess yet again. There are familiar faces, moves, and items throughout, but the experience as a whole feels fresh and focused.
This game is perfect on the go, as you can pop into the game and reach goals in a matter of minutes since there is so much to collect. I felt compelled to stick to the main story of the game although there was plenty to do on the side.
I highly recommend this game if you have a Nintendo Switch, especially if you've ever enjoyed any of Mario's previous games.

Get it, just get it. This is the best game since Mario 64 by far. We‚Äôve had all of the different systems throughout the years and I‚Äôve played lots of games but I‚Äôve always loved Super Mario 64, it‚Äôs stayed in the back of my mind as one of my favorite games and when we bought the switch I thought I would try to see if this has anything similar and after reading the reviews on amazon and people saying it was like that- I had to have it, but I had my doubts.. amazon didn‚Äôt have it at that time, but target had a sale and only two left so I had my husband run to get it. It is what I‚Äôve been waiting for and more!!! It has been the most fun that I‚Äôve had with a game in years!!!!!!! Every chance I get I play. The makers put SOO much detail into every piece of it. It‚Äôs amazingly nostalgic but new and innovative, I honestly just can‚Äôt get enough of it. I never want it to end honestly. If you loved the original Mario platform you will not be disappointed, they mixed that in too. I just had to get on and write a review for this as this game deserves the five stars by far and that‚Äôs the only way for me to say a thank you to the makers!!!!! Worth every penny!!

As is the case with many Nintendo systems, Super Mario Odyssey marked the mustachioed plumber‚Äôs arrival on the Switch, much like Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy did for the Nintendo 64, Gamecube, and Wii, respectively. Taking cues from all its predecessors, Super Mario Odyssey is a gorgeous platformer with plenty to do, almost to its detriment. It‚Äôs clear a lot of attention to detail went into this game, but it‚Äôs also evident that Odyssey is a celebration of Mario‚Äôs history as Nintendo‚Äôs de facto mascot. The fact that you can now play as many of Mario‚Äôs enemies is a fantastic mechanic that is as unique as it is timeless.

Odyssey uses the improved graphics on the Switch to create stunning worlds that are just itching to be explored. The music as well is perhaps some of the best in the franchise, with the theme to the Wooded Kingdom being my absolute favorite. Additionally, while I usually like to play with a pro controller, Odyssey‚Äôs advanced motion controls (likely inherited from the Galaxy games) give Mario that much more mobility and versatility. The diversity of the different worlds was also a welcome change from the more streamlined beach- and space-themed levels from Sunshine and Galaxy, hearkening back to a style reminiscent of Super Mario 64.

While I do appreciate that I can pick up the game at any time and find a few moons that I missed the first time around, the massive amount of collectibles didn‚Äôt urge me to fully complete the game. Sure, there are some expensive costumes that I‚Äôd like to get eventually, but the amount of effort to find everything‚Äîincluding earning some quite difficult power moons‚Äîpushed me away to play other games. After all, once I explored each of the different worlds to satisfy my curiosity, the game had not much more to incentivize me to play past the post-Bowser credits.

A fun gameplay mechanic with plenty (almost too much) to explore, I give Super Mario Odyssey 4.0 stars out of 5.
titles: A fun gameplay mechanic with plenty (almost too much) to explore.

review_contents: What can I say that hasn't been said about this game. After beating the game and collecting 800+ moons, I still want to go back for more. I want to find the last few things I need to capture, get the last few purple coins in each kingdom, buy all the items and clothing, get all the moons in each kingdom. I'm easily 50 hours in and it's the only game I want to play when I turn on the Switch. My other games have been untouched for several weeks. The controls are good, Cappy is a wonderful fresh addition to the Mario series, and there are many hours of wonderful new entertainment packed into this game.
titles: An instant classic and must have for Switch owners

review_contents: I have played a few Nintendo switch games that I was a little disappointed with. This game is one of my favorites. It‚Äôs reminiscent of Mario 64, but unique enough to feel like a totally different experience. There is enough material on the game to keep you entertained for weeks. I love that the game has objectives that are open to the player AFTER bowser is defeated. This open game play is my favorite. I love traveling through levels again with brand new challenges and objectives. Well worth the price tag. Breath of the wild is still my favorite switch game, but this is a close 2nd.

I was excited to play this game after the hype surrounding its release, and for about 20 minutes I was filled with joy. The new hat mechanic was cool, the various jumping options made moving from place to place a lot more like parkour, and the first world has a lot of great detail that makes it interesting to experience at every point.

Unfortunately, the only other world that bears that level of detail is New Donk City and the hat mechanic quickly grows stale. Using parkour to move around the few places on levels that require movement grows tedious, and attempting to walk carefully is nearly impossible given how imprecise Mario's walk/run/stop movements are (he feels slippery, somehow, in a way that adds more frustration to the game than it adds to the experience of puzzles).

Everything but the uneven aesthetic would be excusable if the movement-based puzzles were frequent, varied, and complex. They are not. They are scattered lightly throughout the large, mainly empty levels. Often the solutions are obvious or require only a short amount of consideration-- and once you have solved a few of the puzzles they quickly become trivial.

I aired these grievances on reddit when the game first came out, and was told that the "real game" begins once you have completed the main storyline. By that time, however, I was bored with the puzzles, bored with the aesthetic, and ready to sell my game to someone else.
titles: Large, candy-colored, empty worlds to jump around in

review_contents:
I love this game. Mario games have always been known for having charm, but this one is on steroids. Super Mario Odyssey kept a smile on my face the entire time I was playing it.

If I have one minor complaint, it's that they put too many moons in the game (which I'll admit is much better than if they had put too few in the game). Sometimes moons are so easy or so random to get... you can stumble upon one without even trying.

However, despite this, I can't emphasize how much I enjoyed the game. The plot was good (for a Mario game). The gameplay was outstanding. I don't think Mario has ever controlled so fluidly.

For years, my favorite 3d collect-a-thon was Banjo Kazooie on the N64. However, I believe that Super Mario Odyssey has surpassed BK to become my new favorite.
titles: Super Mario Odyssey is my New Favorite

review_contents: Would have loved to actually review the game but the case, which was sealed on delivery, had no actual cartridge included. Game packaging was also in French.

My 3 year old son just beat the game. He worked so hard and was obsessed with saving the Princess. So imagine his reaction when after finally saving her she almost leaves him on the moon. That little boy cried so hard. He just couldn't understand why she would leave him after he worked so hard to save her. He has been depressed for 2 days.
So, other than the highly flawed ending scene the game is great.

There are so many things to do in this game. So many secret places, items, and side missions. The best part is that each new world looks and plays so different than the last. The controls for Mario and his magic hat seem endless too. Just so many fun options. I would give it 6 stars if I could.

This game has such fluid controls and fun worlds to explore. So many fun collectibles to keep you engaged. Some will be easy to come by, and late ones will require a mastery over the mechanics of the game.

Mario Odyssey, like in Mario 64 goes back to wide open free roaming levels with lots of nooks and crannies to explore and fabulously fun new mechanics to experiment with. This was the game of its year and a must for your collection. Worth the price of the console.
I absolutely love this game! It is very fun and has a lot of stuff to do! If you love Mario and have a Switch, what are you waiting for? Just buy it!
titles: Hands down one of the best Mario games ever.

review_contents: Super Mario Odyssey is a great addition to the family of Mario games. It is light, fun, and extensive (willI ever finish the whole thing???). I highly recommend for fans of Super Mario!

Oh man those stupid power moons! Despite the grind of having to find like 900 hidden moons, this is easily the most epic Mario adventure yet. So many new and lovable characters. The worlds are graphically gorgeous with some truly stunning artwork. Mario‚Äôs cap as a symbiotic main character (Cappy) in the game is a stroke of utter genius. Another stroke of genius let‚Äôs Mario morph into a T. Rex or various other sundry memorable creatures with the magic of Cappy. You could easily get lost in the beauty of this odyssey for hundreds of hours. I surely did!
